The menu at Perilla is super simple and everything is explained as is, if you aren't familiar with Vietnamese food. My friend ordered their Garlic noodles with meat and I opted for exactly the same, but with Veggies and Tofu. We also ordered a plate of their summer rolls to start with. Now, I am not particularly fond of Tofu and was rather disappointed that the chef couldn't eliminate that option for me. Turns out that they pre-make the garnish. Understandable. 

The Garlic noodles were delicious. Not too garlicky that you'd end up with dragon breath and the tofu and veggies we cooked to a crisp. I could barely see any tofu since it was all shredded. My friend loved her order just as much. Their summer rolls were very refreshing on a sunny day. All in all, my tummy was very content with the food.

The restaurant is also very clean. And I loved the ambiance. You don't feel like leaving after your meal since it's a good place to just sit and chitchat 
and no one rushes you out, unlike a lot of other restaurants at SOMA.

Price-wise, it's very reasonable. Out lunch for two came up to $30.

So why only 3 stars? Rude service. Our server could use a smile on his face at the very least. Rudely telling me that the food is premade and cannot be altered doesn't count as good customer service. I realize that lunchtime might not be your favorite hours, but suck it up and stop being grumpy.

PS: I will go back. I loved the noodles!
author: Ranjani S.

description:
This place really deserves 3.5 stars!  Finally got to try this place after hearing a friend constantly rave how great it was!

Tried the BBQ beef with garlic noodles.  Two other people I was with also ordered the same dish! I immediately noticed one of the dishes had significantly less noodles than the other two! 

Overall, the noodles were very garlicky, but also pretty oily.  The meat was well marinated and some pieces were cooked to a medium rare, which is good.

Service was fast and prompt.  I'd probably give it a higher rating if it was cheaper, but $11 for a viet plate with tons of noodles and minimal meat isn't too great!  Plus the vietnamese coffee that costed over $3 bucks was in a tiny glass!  For the size of that, it should cost only $2.  

For the area, this is probably one of the few viet restaurants!  If you work in the area, you should probably try it if you are craving decent vietnamese food.  However, if you can wander out a bit further, Chinatown and TL has much more viet choices... for cheaper too!
author: Tramy V.

description:
Rude service and ok food.

This place is super busy, which I think is due to them being the only Vietnamese lunch place in the neighborhood.  
I ate the papaya salad which was tasty. 
I tried to order the shrimp noodle soup with the noodles on the side.  The guy laughed at me and said no.  I tried to explain that this was important to me and if he could please do this for me, once again he said "NO, soup comes in bowl, shrimp come on the side, now you want noodle on the side too... no"   

My friend ordered the "five spice chicken noodle soup".  You get a bowl of noodle soup, it's the same soup no matter what you order, you get your chicken on a plate on the side.  As far as the "five spices", that's a joke... it's greasy pan fried chicken.  Not even salt and pepper... I recommend they explore their spice rack...

To add to this I had a can of DietCoke for a buck seventy-five... ouch.  Noodle soup was 11 and the salad 10...
author: Lolita D.

description:
If you're craving for Vietnamese food and looking for something cheap, fast, and convenient, this is the place to go.  It's not AUTHENTIC  but it's good enough.

I'm fond of their pork dish with garlic noodles. They give you a heaping amount of noodles; skimpy on the meat; and the vegetables are so so.  But it's enough for you to be full. Don't expect THAN LONG/CRUSTACEANS garlic noodles either.  It's not on the sweeter side.  It's good though - well prepared.  Just an FYI -you'll need to brush your teeth or rinse with mouth wash after cuz the garlic will keep your breath hummin!

Prices are decent for being located in the heart of downtown SF.  Their coffee and Thai tea are decent as well.

Good lunch spot  - I recommend going a little earlier or coming in a little later to beat the rush.
author: Diana M.

description: Went here with this chick and we both enjoyed the noodle soup. I had the beef and she got the chicken. The beef was marinated and well seasoned though probably not the best for noodle dish, its probably better for rice. Noodles were thin vermancelli and broth was a chicken broth. Overall, delicious and for 2 people it was around 25 with tip. Get here at 11:40 for lunch or you will wait forever.
author: B H.

description:
You cannot go to Perilla without at least trying their garlic noodles; whether you end up liking it or not.  Infused with garlic and butter, it was very good and everything I expected as I've tried something similar at other Vietnamese restaurants before.   Since you get a nice sized bed of noodles (along with whatever meat option you choose with your garlic noodles), I found it was also advantageous to just share two plates and give you friend half of your garlic noodles so you can limit the amount of garlic/butter that gets into your system.  The pork was thin, tender, and marinated with a teriyaki type sauce.  For the price, you cannot go wrong in this part of the SOMA Financial District area.  But like Wendy H said, it would have been nice to have more than one little broccoli on your plate.  Two or three little broccolis  would certainly help offset some of that butter that the garlic noodles are marinated in.  

Lunchtime tip: if you don't get here by sharp at noon, be prepared to wait as there is a swarm of people looking for the same less than $10 entrees you are seeking
author: Albie F.

description: Got the 5 spice chicken vermicelli bowl.  Very nicely done.  Good amount.  Nice clean seating.  10 minute wait or so at prime time.  Tasted garlic noodles and they were good, but I wouldn't want a giant plate of them unless I could have my mouth steam-cleaned afterwards.  Fast service.  Good veggies.
author: Marc S.

description:
The line for Perilla is insane. It's always out the door and I can't understand why. The food is average, the prices ridiculous. If I had to guess, they're after the SoMA/FiDi crowd who don't want salad and sandwiches for lunch.

To avoid the wait I ordered take out, five spice chicken with garlic noodles and fried tofu. The fried tofu was really bland. The dipping sauce was even worse that I  ate the tofu by itself. Sprinkling a little salt and pepper on the tofu goes a long way, but I guess they didn't want to waste their time doing that. I've had the five spice chicken with garlic noodles before. They used to serve it with a couple slice of cucumber, but the description on the menu said it came with a side of vegetables. Their idea of a side of vegetables was two little pieces of broccoli. It was so sad, yet laughable.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Five spice chicken w/ garlic noodles:
Kind of pricey for noodles and chicken, but this is in the financial district afterall. I thought the garlic noodles were too heavy for my liking but the chicken was good since the skin was crispy and it wasn't chicken breast! I wish it came with more than just 2 pieces of broccoli..
(grab some candy on your way out and chew a lot of gum if you have a meeting after lunch as the garlic smell is very strong)

Pork chop vermicelli noodle soup:
I enjoyed this more than the garlic noodles since it was a lighter meal. I liked that they gave me the grilled pork chop on a separate plate so that the meat would keep it's charred flavor and wouldn't be soggy in the bowl of soup! I also liked that the noodle soup came with a lot of bean sprouts.
author: Cindy L.

description:
All the Star's are for the Garlic noodles which are out of this world. The rest of the stuff including the Pho and the Staff (I mean people :-)) leave a bad taste ....

There is attitude ....way too much of it ...
author: ani n.

description: The noise factor in this restaurant was so tremendous I could not enjoy my meal. I could not shout that loud to my companion to make myself heard. Gave up and ate in silence. Food was ok.
author: Vivian A.

description: My new favorite place to eat a cheap, unhealthy lunch! I usually come in after working out and get garlic noodles to go. They give you a very large portion for 5 bucks. The staff is not super nice, but they get the job done.
author: Julia D.

description:
Garlic noodles, garlic noodles, garlic noodles. Need I say more? 

Side note: do not order the pho. it's incredibly bland. 

BUT! Garlic noodles, garlic noodles, garlic noodles. 

Also, if planning to dine in, I suggest you go before noon or after 2. Otherwise, just call in and do pick up. It's not worth the wait to sit down, then pay tip.
author: Yunah R.

description:
Puff the magic dragon lives by the sea because he eats a lot of Perilla Garlic Noodles, and has a major case of dragon breath.  

The Garlic Noodles are the showstopper dish at Perilla.  You get Lo Mein style drenched in garlic flavoring and quite a bit a butter.  They could actually be bettered served with a little less butter as the dish is pretty rich.  You can pair it with different proteins, pork, beef, chicken, veggies, prawns.  I think the go to is the pork chops.

Definitely come here early or late during lunch time.  Forget about trying to dine in if you get in around 12-12:30.
author: Kyle W.

description: The garlic noodles are unbelievable. Awesome comfort food. I had the five spice chicken, I wish the chicken was a little more flavorful but still very good. I would definitely come back here!
author: Juliana D.

description:
My coworker loved this place so much that she got a group of us together to chip in money to order from here for lunch. The day came and she told us all to come to the lunch room. There in our own to-go boxes were garlic noodles with beef or shrimp, I chose the beef. I'm not sure if she separated the food into each box so that we'd all get equal portions- I just know it smelled so garlicky! I was too busy to eat it right away, so it was a little cold when I got to it. Even at room temp this food was good! 

The garlic noodles were yuuummy- I didn't think anything could compare to Thanh Long or Crustaceans... Perilla comes pretty close. The beef had tons of flavor- it was marinated quite well and it was nice and tender! This says a lot for food that was warmed up again. 

Later, I got an email from my other coworker, "Was it me? Or was that the best effin beef ever?" 

It effin was!
author: S Y.

description:
Shrimp DUMPLINGS? Just the word dumplings sets me off. What Taiwanese girl can resist dumplings!!? Mmm. I ordered a plate of these dumplings and it came with a spicy soy sauce that topped it off. It was delicious!! I would order this again. Good job, Perilla.

Perilla makes pretty mean garlic noodles but it definitely doesn't top Thanh Long's. It still goes well with the meat that you order though. We ordered a chicken dish with noodles and it was good. A bit on the oily side but the green onions went well with each chicken bite. The egg rolls here remind me of the Pho place on Irving between 19th and 20th (but those taste better, more meat!)

I met the owner Tim and he's an awesome guy. He also owns the Pho place on Irving so definitely check out that place if you've been to Perilla and like it. 

I'll be back during my 1 hour lunch breaks!

(Photos Uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
I am such a garlic noodle lover but nothing ever compared to Thanh Long, until I found Perillas. 

For around $10, you get a heaping pile of steamy noodles full or garlicky goodness, with a side of thinly sliced steak, 5-spice chicken, prawns or a variety of other items. Don't like garlic noodles? Its okay, you can get it with rice, too. 

Oh, and their Thai iced tea is perfect - not too sweet and oh-so refreshing! The portions are generous - I always have leftovers. But they don't last long : )

Tips:
- The crowd gathered outside everyday at lunchtime is the proof that this place is GOOD. So my advice is get there early (11:30-ish) or take a late lunch if you want to avoid the crowd. 
- When you walk in, you must put yourself on the waiting list - write your name and # in your party on the clipboard in front. I've seen lots of people standing around and lose their place in line because they don't do this.
- No time for a sit-down lunch? No worries. You can call your order in and come pick it up. They move quickly, so they'll only need about 5-10 minutes to get your order ready.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Wow, a non-fancy Vietnamese joint that doesn't serve pho!  It slightly reminds me of those non-authentic Chinese joints that serve huge bland broccoli as the vegetable.  That being said, sometimes you want greasy noodles and overly seasoned/salted meat.  You can definitely do much worse in the FiDi for lunch.

Imperial Roll: Standard.  Nothing to impress, but what you'd expect.  Good fried shell and filling... could have used more spices in the pork.

Charbroiled Beef: Was similar to the overly flavored and overly well done beef found in quick beef teriyaki bowls.  I enjoyed it for its fast food goodness.

Garlic Noodles: A little dry.  Very garlicky.  Seemed more Italian than Vietnamese.  Definitely a step above plain rice on the excitement scale.  Came with some steamed broccoli that was large and boring.
author: Adam B.

description: It's true, the garlic noodles are so good. Had it with curry chicken which was decent.
author: Xteethx B.

description:
Not sure how I feel about Perilla..... Vegetarian options are very limited, the garlic noodles were pretty good but then again, it's noodles drenched in butter and garlic, how can you screw that up? They have vegetarian egg rolls but would not serve them over the vermicelli noodles even though there's a vermicelli with pork egg rolls option on the menu... A coworker asked for beef and chicken over vermicelli and getting that figured out was a mess in itself. Half and half is a no go and a small side of beef is $5? Fine, just make it already. Food came out really quickly but otherwise we had to flag down the waiter every time we needed something. I would be hard pressed to come back considering my only menu option is garlic noodles with a side of vegetables for nearly $10. 3 stars for you!

Can someone explain to me why a Vietnamese restaurant is serving Thai Iced Tea?
author: Joy B.

description: Came here with my co-workers last week.  The food was ok.  I had a beef salad, since I'm on a low carb diet.  The funny things is, it wasn't even lettuce, more like thin strips of beets with a good portion of beef and sweet dressing (not my preference).  The price wasn't bad at $11.  To be fair, the noodle and meat dishes looked sooooo good, if I wasn't on my diet, I would have chosen that instead.  The service was good, friendly and accommodating.   Overall, not bad.  If you decide to come here for lunch, make sure to come early, like 11:30am otherwise you'll be wait a long time to get a table..
author: Mike M.

description: I tried their 5 Spice Chicken Noodle Soup ($10) because a co worker recommended this place.  The chicken was boneless with semi crispy skin, served on the side.  The soup it self was quite bland, and was luke warm as the waitress brought it out.  I should've known better and ask them to heat it up some more, because about 2 hours later, I got an upset stomach for the rest if the day.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Finally, a solid Vietnamese restaurant in the FiDi.  I always found it odd that a super quick and efficient operation like a Vietnamese restaurant never made its way to the busy FiDi, where 9-to-5 minions need to get their quick noontime sustenance.  I know there's Pho Hoa in Embarcadero 3, but why go there when all you hear about it is that it's overpriced and disgusting?

Perilla must be owned by Chinese people.  I've only heard Cantonese or Mandarin come out of the mouths of the employees here.  And not a lick of Vietnamese.  Another sure sign that this place is owned by Chinese people is the giant "Grand Opening 08.08.08" banner hanging outside.  Yep, that's so Chinese.

Though their menu is not the typical 100+ item menu you see in Vietnamese restaurants, I like it for its simplicity and it makes for easier decision-making.  After a few visits, I've decided that my favorite item is the charbroiled beef ($8.50) with garlic noodles (add $1.50, for pho too--no additional cost for rice or vermicelli).  Their beef is juicy and tender, but the garlic noodles...mmmmmmm, so good.  The noodles are fresh egg noodles, mixed in with a whole lot of garlic powder and minced garlic.  They leave my breath smelling...well, garlicky.  And it seems that many people in my office have caught on to their tasty garlic noodles because the office is smelling a lot more garlicky these days. 

Their charbroiled pork, charbroiled prawns and grilled pork spring rolls are great choices too.  The portions are quite generous, sometimes I have enough for the next day's lunch.  This place is really popular during lunch, so call in your order and bring it back to the office instead.  Plus, I think they give you more when you order to go!
author: Diane L.

description:
12.03.10

Buttery, garlic noodles FTW!

Heaping portion to boot.

No wonder there's always a line here.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The wait is excruciating.  

Only because their garlic noodles are truly delish.  It just takes FOREVER for them to get your order ready.  Phone in and give yourself a good 15 minutes before heading over to pick it up - if you're as impatient as me.
author: Kristen S.

description:
i'm  never felt so cheated before! i bought some appetizer imperial rolls -- $6.00 so it came out to $6.57 with tax. I got 6 TINY and i mean TINY half cut (so that would be 3 ACTUAL ROLLS!!!!)...making them $1 dollar a piece. ive lived in san francisco my whole life and ive been to probably a dozen places that served imperial rolls and never have i been charged this much for something  i KNOW costs really little to make. 

i dont care if all the other food is good there. the fact that they can charge something that CLOSE to highway robbery...me thinks i will never go back. i work just a block away but am willing to walk blocks away for lunch! i'm not a cheap person but i am a reasonable one...
author: Cicely T.

description:
Thanks, Yelp! So, what do you do when you're charged with taking people you don't know to lunch in a city that you don't live in? Well, I hear there's this cool website that connects people to great local businesses.... and, guess what? It works!

I was in the mood for some Asian eats and Perilla did not disappoint. I was a bit uncertain as when we arrived, the place was slammed. But, the line moved quickly and we were seated within minutes. Even though this is a Viet place, I started with some Thai Iced tea. I am an addict. I might have been the most familiar with Vietnamese food at my table, so I suggested we start with some shrimp rolls and these were very nicely done. Rather than rolls, I would call them 'sausages.' They were girthy (is that a word) and packed with ingredients -- including big, lovely, skrimps. For my entree, I order the 5-spice chicken vermicelli. The bowl was huge. Again, it was packed with ingredients and I observed as much chicken as I did vegetables (the mint, sprouts and onion come to mind). And, all this for $7. That's a fantastic lunch-time value. I couldn't finish it all... and I can eat. The best part of the meal, however, was breaking bread with two new friends/co-workers and re-affirming that there are phenomenal people in every department of this cool company that's silly enough to employ me. Cheers all around.

Oh, snap! I just remembered that I left my leftovers in the company fridge. I hope someone threw them away by now. It's got to be pretty rank. Or, if you ate it, you're welcome. I'll send you a bill.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I had always passed this place during weekend when it is closed, so today I was very excited to be able to have lunch here. Since I was in a rush, I chose to grab to go.

The menu was very simple. No matter what you order ( rice, Garlic Noodle, vermicelli, and noodle soup) , you have choices to go with it, including chicken, beef, prawn, pork, pork chops, veggies. All of the lunch plates are around $10.

It was very easy for me. I love Vietnamese Soup Noodles so I chose it.
When I order, I told the guy at the cashier that I want Pork Chop Soup Noodles, but later when I look at my receipt it was garlic noodles. I told him to change it, and he appeared to be very impatient and he was in a very bad attitude. I was really not happy about paying $ 11 for lunch and have to in exchange for a bad attitude. So service was bad. I will not go back to the place again.

For food, Pork Chop is good. However, there are 40% of the meat were fat. For soup noodle, it was very salty and it was very plan tasting.

Definitely don't recommend this place compare to other delicious Vietnamese places in the city.
author: Angel W.

description:
For starters, I all but ran to the elevator after a co-worker told me about her meal at this new place, Perilla, and handed me a copy of the menu.  Inexpensive Vietnamese a block away?!  And she said it was "grubbin'!"  Zoom...

I sped over to the location, next to Portico, where a seriously-sorry-looking Chinese place had been, to find a simple, slightly-stylish dining room with no line (at 1pm).  From what I observed, they are quick to take your order, but food delivery speed varies greatly.  One guy "got his pho on" in just a couple of minutes, my charbroiled prawns took a little longer, a guy at the table next to me was near tears because his tablemate was almost finished eating by time his food arrived (I'm only exaggerating about the tears part).  

It's a small menu which makes ordering easy, and I'm sure keeps food costs down for the owners.  So you have four charbroiled choices: beef, prawns, chicken, pork and pork chops.  Plus, Five-spice chicken, a plump drumstick, they claim.  The imperial roll looks like a good deal at $2.30.  

The prawns were super-tasty, the rice very ordinary, and the broccoli only OK.  For some reason the water tasted funky.  Next time I'll try the vermicelli or garlic noodles with my meal.  I had on a white shirt and was on my way to a couple of meetings, so I didn't want to chance tricky noodle action.  

The team service was mostly fast, but there were a few problems.  Yes, they were quick to refill my bad water.  Yes, you get seated and order in a snap.  But since no one person is responsible for your table, no one notices if your order doesn't come out...like the poor chap praying for his grub next to me.  And when I was ready to leave, it took a long azz time (technical term) to get my check and a longer azz time to get someone to take my money.  I literally had to turn around in my seat and stare at the gossiping/chillin' crew behind the counter to get someone to come so I could give them my cash.  Yeah, relax the lunch rush is over...I get it.  But some of us worker bees need your help so we can get back to the hive.  

All this being said, I'm a fan.  There's not nearly enough Vietnamese in this town for my taste.  And downtown needs more reasonably-priced decent lunch spots like this. Welcome Perilla!  3 stars for lunch (4 stars on the downtown scale).  I'll definitely be back.  Still, I found Perilla to be a mixed bag on this single visit.  Maybe they're still working out the kinks.  They could easily slide up to be a real 4 stars...I'll keep you posted...
author: Ted R.

description:
The restaurant was very clean and the decor was nice for a casual sit-down. Unfortunately, I just wasn't impressed. We had a good sample of the menu:

-Garlic noodles with beef; because it's what they are known for
-Noodle soup (Pho) with five spiced chicken; because it was cold
-Imperial rolls: Egg rolls filled with ground pork + etc; because most restaurants don't mess this up

They definitely give you a LOT of carbs here. Maybe I've just had too much of the authentic stuff. These three items were consistently bland and oily. It was expensive for what it was and I've just had better. 

=/
author: Kathy H.

description:
I have to semi-retract the iced coffee comment one more time-- they did pre-made the coffee as I saw them take it out from the fridge and all the ice cubes were actually solidified into 1 big one. Though the girl said it's fresh and they made it in the morning... hmmm... must say though it did save me time from waiting at the counter... and I am soooo addddddicted to it!

I also tried their charbroiled prawn on cold vermicelli which was very good. Prawns were done just right and not overcooked.
author: T L.

description:
Sometimes I hate waiting to get a table at this place.. As soon as that's over, the process begins...
I sit down and wait, and wait, and wait. Sometimes it seems like the waiter will never come.

And just when I'm about to leave, the waiter arrives. 
Usually they ask only once for my order, but sometimes twice, or even three times. Sure enough, they'll get it right.

Enough about the service...

The garlic noodles with beef is delicious. If I could review this place based on the food alone all would be ok... 
Every now then between my meal I need to drink water and then the process of waiting begins all over again. 
Sometimes, I am lucky to have my cup filled twice in one sitting....

All in all, a good place to eat but make sure you leave yourself enough time to dine in here.

Great food. Terrible service.
author: Ignacio A.

description: You have to sign in if its crowded. 5-spice chicken with garlic noodles was good hence the 3***'s.  Don't expect them to refill your water or get you anything more once they drop off your food. We had to flag them down a few times.
author: Nancy F.

description:
A solid 3.5 stars for Perilla (Yelp should give us 1/2 star ratings!). We came here for a midweek lunch and ordered the char boiled pork bun (vermicelli noodles) ($8), shrimp spring roll ($6), and Vietnamese coffee $3.25.

The food is authentic and very decent price for the noodles which were tasty and flavorful. The spring rolls could have used a little bit more shrimp but the vermicelli noodles were soft and you could tell they just made the spring rolls.  The Vietnamese coffee doesn't come in the traditional french drip so I was a little cautious but it was very flavorful and sweet..So good I wanted another one but not for $3.25.

Would definitely frequent this place again if we are in the mood for Vietnamese food in the area.
author: Betty C.

description:
Are you kidding! This is the best Vietnamese food in the FiDi. Hands down the most excellent garlic noodles (it will make your friends think you just went to the Gilroy Garlic Festival, but whatevs). I am a huge fan of the Prawns as well as the Five Spice Chicken. The salads are also fresh, and delish. 

This place gets crazy packed at lunch time, but it is good for a quick sit down lunch, don't give up you will get in usually after about a 10 min. wait at the most. 

Price is right as well- about $15 for two for lunch. Don't forget a tall glass of Thai tea!
author: Sarah M.

description: Not bad!  Got the pho, and was at first disappointed not to receive the usual accouterments (lime, peppers, hoisin sauce, etc).  However, the meat quality and broth just about made up for it!
author: Corey C.

description: A simple approach - pick a meat, then pick a starch (garlic noodes, rice vermicelli cold or in a soup, rice), eat. Whatever spices they use on the chicken/pork/beef work for me. Plus it's pretty cheap.
author: Mi M.

description:
Wow. I need to get out of my 2 block radius FiDi self-imposed restaurant restriction. I've become so lazy with my lunch options that everytime someone in my department asks, "whats for lunch?!" i reply like a zombie, "julie's kitchen, cafe venue, mixed greens, thai thai....um, that's all i got." I met a friend for lunch here on the other side of Market and it was a whole new world (including a new lee's - whoa!). Perilla is a cozy little place and was super packed at 11:50 for lunch. We waited about 15 minutes and then split the garlic noodles (Mmmmm....garlic noodles) with chicken curry, which they are apparently famous for, and a green papaya salad with shrimp. Loved the noodles and chicken, wasn't too crazy about the salad til I got to the bottom. I guess I should have mixed it because all the yummy juices were at the bottom. 

The only downside to this place was the wait and the hover-ers who hover over you as you eat, waiting for you to finish. I have a new place to add in my repetoire so it was a success.
author: Hanan H.

description:
Mmmm garlic noodles - YUM!  I love coming in here every time I am in town because I tend to crave for these noodles when I'm down in S.America. 

This place is amazing and so delicious. The portions are a good size and their grilled meat is done to a perfect crisp.  

I recommend this place to anyone who wants to have a good and hearty meal.
author: Liza B.

description: The main event for lunch are the tasty garlic noodles although they are not a very balanced meal.  The menu describes them as "noodles with vegetables".  I'm not sure two slices of cucumber should qualify as "vegetables", especially at around $9.  They have a $6.50 option that isn't as big of a starch bomb but that version doesn't even come with cucumber.  More vegetables alone would earn this place another star from me.
author: Carlin F.

description:
After going back a 2nd time, I finally tried the Curry Chicken Vermicelli. It was good, especially on a rainy cold day. Tried the Pho, the Garlic Noodles, and the chicken before plus a few other dishes and they were also pretty good. I would have originally given this 3 stars but after the Curry, the place deserves 4 stars. 

They run out of food alot, and haven't tried the Bo Bu Lac yet, the wait sometimes suck, but overall the staff are attentive.

4 stars for the food alone.
author: Mike W.

description: Not a lot of options to choose from (they have 5-6 options with choice of protein). I got the garlic noodles with five spice chicken which was recommended to me. The noodles themselves were good and the portion was pretty hefty. The edible parts of the chicken were decent but my chicken had way too much fat and gristle. A coworker who got the pho (which isn't even called pho on the menu) said it was rather unspectacular. Next time I think I'll actually venture into Chinatown for a more authentic meal. Overall not bad per say but nothing to rave about.
author: Gannon M.

description: Favorite pork spring rolls across the land (usually), but since when were they 8 freaking bucks!! Finished em and they were mediocre today :/
author: Lauren Q.

description:
if you go here without ordering the garlic noodles, you are a FOOL.

DO IT!


it can get busy for lunch so be careful...
author: Shawn A.

description:
Their Garlic Noodles were BOMB. 
I got the Five Spices Chicken Garlic Noodle and yum, the chicken was really crispy on the outside but really tender on the inside. 
The two just mixed so well!

BUT, 4 stars for their service. We were on a time crunch because we came in between our lunch break during work but they completely forgot about our order or something because other people who came in after us got their food before us. We ended up having to wait over 30 minutes for our food to come out and we only had 10 minutes to finish it. 

Basically, the food is good but their service isn't. I'd still come back for their garlic noodles.
author: Julia K.

description:
This is the perfect place to come to grab lunch during the hectic work week. 

Food: probably one of the things they are most famous for, are their garlic noodles.  Surprisingly, they give you a lot of noodles when you order! The portion size is good for the price you get.  I always order the garlic noodles + charbroiled pork. omgggg, its good.  And they even serve it with my favorite: fresh sliced cucumbers and sauteed green onions! Every time I go here, I pretty much always order the same thing.  Lots of people are eating the noodle soups, and they look delish! 

Ambiance: the place is relatively small.  Whenever I go around lunch time, there is usually at least a 5-10 minute wait, regardless of party size.  It might be a good idea to head there around 11:30ish.  Inside the restaurant is nice and kind of modern.  It is always clean! 

Price: great price for what you get! 

Service: the service is quick (because I think they know most of the people there are looking for a quick lunch break and then back to work).  

Overall, this is a great place to come for lunch! I've never been here for dinner, but I assume it is just as good.  Make sure you order something that includes garlic noodles. 

*drooooool* so good!
author: Ashley M.

description: I can't think of a better place for delicious garlic noodles and pork chops. A great place for an elaborate lunch.
author: Prashanth C.

description:
Came here to eat lunch the other day and was not impressed. Ad a fan of garlic noodles I was pretty excited after reading other peoples reviews, but in reality, I probably could have done better making them at home. That being said, the food wasn't overly greasy and did not take forever. At 1:30 the place was almost empty.

As always it's challenging to find good vegetarian options at Vietnamese restaurants, but they seem to be making an honest effort here. There were at least three things that were veggie on the menu.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Why is this place on my list of venues to review?  I don't even remember coming here but I must have b/c I've apparently checked-in.  Oh wait, I do remember now, came here for lunch right before the lunch rush at around 11:45.  Good luck if you come post-rush... folks were waiting out the door.

Food is alright, pretty pricey but par for the course in this area during lunch.  Didn't venture to try their highly acclaimed garlic noodles b/c i didn't want to subject my coworkers to the aftermath...
author: Ricky S.

description: The garlic noodles are fairly good, but that's pretty much your entire meal. If you don't mind that, it's a nice place to eat.
author: Amber Y.

description:
I have never really gone wrong with this place. I usually get the garlic noodles with some meat. I honestly just want the noodles. If only garlic didn't leave that smell of well garlic :) But I do realize I should at least have some protein. The chicken or the pork or whatever meat is actually my least favorite thing. It's usually kind of rubbery and while tasting ok, texturewise sort of freaks me out. If I remember correctly, they do have coconut curry for those days when I want to just go all out. Pretty good and pretty convenient and gets sort of busy for lunch.

Definitely come here for take out (listen for your order though people are usually vultures). Dining in offers really no benefit. Service is sort of non existent and my friend pointed out that they have wooden chopsticks on the tables that they wash and reuse. Sort of gross in a restaurant setting. So either ask for silverware or ask for a set of wrapped chopsticks.
author: Greg G.

description: Garlic noodles with beef was great although I wanted the five spice chicken. The chicken looked better but someone at the table ordered it so as a rule I could not. The service wasn't super attentive but who cares i didn't need anything.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Oooh, Perilla.  You take my stomach away.

Although I've only eaten there once, it's become one of my new favorite eateries.  Garlic noodles is all I need to say.

Go early.  Eat at 10:30 or after 1 if you must (or better, take it away and eat it outdoors if it's nice); there should be no crowds.  However, despite the deposits of people hanging around the door, the tables turn quickly and food is served pronto.  We had a very anxious waiter trying to turn our table over when I barely finished my meal.  Maybe I need to eat faster?

Even when a meal is kind of spendy, if there are leftovers, it's worth it in my book.   Thanks fellow Yelper C.!

Glorious oodles of noodles. More soon please.
author: Jen L.

description:
My co-workers and I love coming here for lunch. Don't come here around 12 o'clock because they can get packed and you will be waiting for over 20 minutes for a table. We always come around 12:30-1pm when we know we're heading here for lunch. 

I always get the 5 spice chicken with garlic noodles. Yum!
The portion is large enough to fill you up. And do expect to want to take a nap after your meal. 

One of my favorite lunch spots.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Yum! This place is delicious!!!

My friend and I went here and split garlic noodles with beef, pork chops on rice and the papaya salad. Everything was so good! If I had to choose one I would say go for those garlic noodles and beef. Then overindulge and please eat the pork, it was so good and perfectly cooked, tender without it too raw and definitely not overdone.

Not pricey for a lunch in SF. Expect to pay about $10.00 an entree.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Mmmm I had the beef with garlic noodles!! The smell of it overwhelmed the office:). The dish is really oily but sooo good!! 

If I have the chance, I'd try the Five Spice Chicken next time.
author: Linda L.

description:
I ordered to my tastes and got the garlic noodles with the beef. The beef tasted of lemongrass (I love lemongrass) and the noodles were just so buttery and reeking of garlic in the best way possible. It came with some nuoc cham and cucumber slices.

I was not at all disappointed. For the price you get a hell of a lot of noodles. And they're really good so you're putting a dent in the pile, yet when you're full there's still enough noodles and meat left for a whole other lunch!

My friend and I also shared the fried spring rolls, which were crispy yet chewy. These were so good that they may account for not finishing our mains. You get 3 large rolls cut in half (I think), which is filling, and the wrapper was the fresher kind, so it was kind of bubbly from being fried. Such a satisfying meal. Aaand I'm making myself hungry again.

I will definitely come back, but next time I'll beat the lunch rush. This place gets really busy and there's usually a line out the door. If you're waiting outside make sure to go in and put your name on the list. I saw quite a few people picking up takeaway orders, too.

There's pho and curries as well. My friend's chicken curry was good. I doubted the pho options because I like traditional pho restaurants with all the cow part options, but the soups did look really good.

You can get a better lunch deal elsewhere, but for the quality of the food and the sheer amount, it's totally worth it. Think of it as paying over $10 for lunch but getting two meals, especially when you order the garlic noodles.
author: Amy N.

description:
This is a 3.5 star rating.

Very good garlic noodles -- not as good as those at the now closed Annalien (Napa) -- but good nonetheless.  I had the five spice chicken with them -- the chicken had wonderfully crispy skin and moist meat, but I didn't get any hint of spice (let alone 5 spices).

The grilled pork rolls were good, but may be a bit too many noodles for my taste.  The pork was tender and had good flavor.

The service was friendly, but could have been more attentive at the start.  I arrived around 11 am and there were only 2 other tables, yet no one came to take my order for 10 minutes or so (despite there being  a dearth of uniformed employees wandering around).

Despite some shortfalls, I'd eat here again.

Still mourning the loss of Annalien.  And, still in search of outstanding garlic noodles (Bui Bistro in Napa doesn't cut it) -- going to try Crustacean or Thahn Long next!
author: Dana R.

description:
Chicken Garlic Noodles, it was tasty and yummy.

I just love Garlic, the more garlic, the better it is.

BTW, I don't think it's really Vietnamese, but oh well, it was still good!

I made the mistake of coming here right before a meeting, whoops!
author: Eric A.

description:
i fell in love with this place the first time i went here.  My brother kept telling me that we needed to be there by 11:15am because the line would get crazy.  I figured, okay, why not?  So we arrived right at 11:15 and there was only one table left by the window.  I was shocked that it was so packed that early on a friday!  We ordered the garlic noodles with beef and a rice plate of the sliced pork.  I always try the imperial rolls when I go to a vietnamese restaurant, so I ordered one with my meal for an addt'l $2.  Each meal was about $10-12.  the food was excellent!!!  Each table around us had an order of the garlic noodles... i could tell it was their specialty.  Overall, I would say my experience was very good.  It took us a very long time to get our check despite the long line of people because the servers were busy serving food!

The next time I went there, i took my boss.  We got an order of the imperial rolls - she loved them so much she ate 4 pieces!  My one complaint is how packed it got around 12pm.  It got so crowded that people started leaning into our table as we ate, it was NOT sexy to have someone's ass resting on the seat while were trying to eat in peace.

Decent prices for very good food.
author: Marylouise R.

description: Garlic noodles over hyped. Small portions. Not going back.
author: Chris M.

description:
This is a block from my office and during a trip to another lunch place I spotted this place, busy with people coming in and out like honey bees to a hive.  I went on Yelp and found out the details and later in the week I came to try it with 2 coworkers.

You have a few choices to mix and match noodles or rice with a few types of meat.  Throw on some sriracha sauce and lime and your sinus' will instantly clear. I had the 5 spice chicken and rice. Quite good and look forward to trying other items on the menu. I went and dined in for lunch, but you can do take out as well.
author: Ryan D.

description:
-1 for the price.

$10.40 for noodles and some cooked veggies is too much, BUT I suppose since I've been there twice now, it is the market price.

Why, you ask?  Because the noodles are just perfectly prepared - slightly fried, slightly soft, a nice thickness, and covered in garlic.

Definitely a great lunch place if you don't mind the price.  Would be nice if they had more vegetarian options though.
author: Jon M.

description:
Had lunch here with my sister. A bit of a wait if you get here past 11:30 (we arrived at 11:40) and many other customers waiting took their orders to go. It seems to be a lunch hot spot for the businesses surrounding it. 

The menu is simple, which I appreciate. You get your meat or vegetable selection paired with garlic noodles or vermicelli. There are pho options as well. 

We had beef and pork chop with garlic noodles and vermicelli. Both were tasty and satisfying though I feel the garlic noodles can be a bit on the greasy side. The imperial rolls were a good way for us to start and though fried, did not feel oily at all. 

Service can be spotty. As it does get busy, the waiters are running around everywhere trying to keep up and you can get lost in the shuffle if you don't aggressively flag them down. 

Still, solid food at reasonable prices make this a good place to grab lunch.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
I have been walking by this place for years without even noticing it, but yesterday some friends suggested meeting here for lunch.  We got there around noon and probably waited 20+ minutes for a table for 3.  I suggest getting here before 11:45 if you are in a hurry.  

I was feeling a little under the weather and the GIANT bowl of noodle soup was just what the doctor ordered.  The broth was flavorful but light.  I ordered it with the five spice chicken which came on the side so it wasn't soggy.  Very tasty and I even had a FULL to-go container of soup left.  All for a reasonable price. 

Imperial rolls were good too.
author: Meagan C.

description:
A lone Vietnamese spot in the ramble of SOMA office buildings means you can expect a wait during lunch time, if you want to eat in. I recommend foregoing the straightforward, no frills experience- call in your order and go to one of the nearby park areas if you want a more relaxing meal and conversation.

Not many veggie options on the limited menu. The plain "garlic noodles" says it comes with a side of veggies. If you say "veggie garlic noodles" when you order apparently they just heap on more of the mushroom/cabbage/carrot shredded slaw and charge you more. So don't order it that way! 

Otherwise affordable, sizable portions.
author: Kim K.

description:
4 starts for the only thing i've tried on the menu...twice.  

Five Spice Chicken with GARLIC NOODLES! yum!

Gets crowded during lunch so get there early or order to-go...they whip up the entrees super fast.
author: Elaine L.

description:
There's no better Vietnamese lunch spot around in the Financial District. The menu offering showcases tasty garlic noodles with any dish, excellent chicken salad, and my favorite the BBQ pork dish. Except that's about all they do which is pretty slim for a Vietnamese restaurant. If the food wasn't so good, I would demand the 1st page of the menu and order some Pho!

And the lunch crowd is pretty crazy.
author: Vien T.

description: I liked the rice dishes quite a bit... But if the staff doesn't speak Vietnamese then ffs please at least speak English... This is the financial district... It should not take 10 mins to try to ask for no meat and peanuts... My coworker had to explain to the waitress she doesn't eat meat 4 times...
author: Nathan D.

description:
Oh garlic noodles, I love noodles in general! =) This is definitely their specialty here and is the only other place that serves garlic noodles outside of the Sunset and Richmond District. 

How's the FIVE SPICE Chicken with vermicelli you ask? Taste more like no spice FATTY chicken with vermicelli, seriously, no flavor! Whatever happen to the concept of marinating??!! Did they just chop a chicken (hye ya), throw it on the grill, let it sizzle for a couple of minutes and plate it? Thank goodness for the nuoc mam, my lifesaver! You can never go wrong with adding fish sauce! 

I'll most likely come back with my coworkers, they seem to enjoy the food here!
author: Leeseuh K.

description: Garlic Noodles!!!  Need I say more???
author: Jennifer H.

description: I walked in my first time eating there and the woman welcomed me and began to push a button and I said I'd like to order the 5 spice chicken and garlic noodles and she said I know. They know how good it is! They must put out 100 of these a day easy. It was delicious and I'd absolutely order it again.
author: Adam H.

description:
Solid lunch spot, best for take-out or a quick sit-down-and-stuff-face 1-on-1 lunch before running back to the office.  Hard to relax and enjoy your grub here, as it gets crowded and becomes a zoo for pick-up orders.

No surprise that it's so busy, the food is good and service is lightning quick.  I always get the chicken, and I'll upgrade to garlic noodles if I don't have any afternoon meetings.  Good stuff.
author: Gary D.

description:
So far I've only tried the five spice chicken garlic noodles, but I enjoyed every bite of it.  It's very garlic-y and a little buttery too though, so maybe only good once in a while.  It was a little pricier (~$10) than I anticipated for it being lunchtime and for the dish consisting primarily of starch, but they do at least give a hefty amount protein (chicken in my case).

Pretty fast too if you want to call in or walk in and take out.
author: Alex C.

description:
YAY - I was missing Sai's after moving to the other side of Market St., but not we have Perilla! I've only been once but LOVED the green papaya salad with grilled steak on it. Great flavor, filling (even for this piggy girl) and quick. I'd prefer not to spend $9+ for lunch but whatya gonna do...can't get Subway's $5 footlong everyday.

Take out at Noonish was quick - 10 min wait, but the place was packed. I'm assuming that service is quick enough to sneak back to work without your boss noticing.
author: Deann M.

description:
This is my new go to lunch spot. Great summer rolls (far better that thai spots nearby) and full of veggies -- not noodles. 
Speaking of noodles the garlic noodles are absolutely addicting. I stick with the side order for 3.50 which is a meal, albeit unbalanced, in itself. I've had papaya salad with shrimp which was good, but have had better.  Looking forward to trying some of the veggie, curry chicken and rice dishes soon!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Being a hardcore Sunsetizen (or whatever you call someone who lives in the Sunset), a lover of Vietnamese food, and a lover of restaurants two blocks from my apartment, the only Perilla I had been to was the one on Irving.  I love that Perilla something fierce, so I was particularly stoked when one of my coworkers suggested we go out to lunch to the Perilla nearby our office.

The food did not disappoint.  I had the vermicelli with veggies and some summer roll, and both of those things were delicious.  The cabbage was sweet, the mushrooms had the right amount of chewy-to-crunchy ratio, the tofu was a little sweet, and the noodles covered in fish sauce and Siracha were cool, smooth, and mysteriously hearty.  I'm a relatively new convert to summer rolls, too, but Perilla makes some of the best ones I've had - all the snap and crunch of fresh veggie inside a chewy, sticky rice paper!

Another interesting thing to note is that, though the menu seems small at first glance, there are at least a bajillion different ways to combine a handful of basic ingredients that kept me looking at my neighbors' meals thinking "Ooh!  I wonder what that is?"  And believe me - it all looks so good.

I highly recommend thou get thee to a Perilla, but better to make it the one on Irving.  I'm not sure what it's like for dinner, but at lunch it was positively mobbed.  I know the waitstaff was doing its best, but my coworker was told they could seat a party of eight, only to find out once we got there that they meant they could seat a party of eight at two or three separate tables.  (Eight is a pretty huge number and it doesn't bother me they couldn't seat us together, only that they made it seem like they could).  The food wasn't long in coming out, but for anything else we wanted, we had to actually get up and find a server to help us.  And it was definitely noisy - I'm actually a bit surprised that such a small place can echo so well!

So, not really the place to go for a quiet or intimate meal, but if you can make it on an off hour or make it out to the Inner Sunset, it's absolutely worth it: if nothing else, the food will leave you thinking "Hey, baby, where you BEEN all my life?"
author: Becca S.

description:
Fail, I am not going back. I ordered garlic noodles and 5 spice chicken which I thought the BEST menu, based on yelp and my friend's review. But turns out garlic noodles were greasy and tasteless, I just tasted garlic, that's all. Chickens were full of fat as well. It's like the americanized vietnamese, really.. I love vietnamese food so I know how it should be like. Their garlic noodles are nothing compared to Crustacean (or Thanh Long) and even PPQ.

Well maybe it's just my experience because everybody seem to love Perilla. I came in 30 minutes before they closed at 3 pm, so I might got the leftover which were not that fresh. However because of that traumatic greasy and buttery experience, sorry but I may not coming back to try on their other menus.
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
I whole-heartedly recommend the grilled pork or five-spice chicken. Always seasoned perfectly and a satisfying portion.  One thing I'd like to know though:  which five spices?  I really want to know!

Minus one star because of the crowds and noise.  For best blood pressure results, have an early or late lunch there.
author: Rosie M.

description:
This place has the best papaya salad! The service is not too friendly, but they're efficient enough. If you go at 11 am, you beat the lunch crowd. I had the beef garlic noodles; it was alright, the noodles were chow mein style, which I didn't care for, but the beef was good.

I would definitely come back, if only for the salad.
author: Jessica D.

description: So I finally had lunch here.. I had the beef with garlic noddles and it was delish.. Yes I did tried to hurt myself and finish the whole dish. But make sure you have plenty of gum or mints, cause you will need them. With all the garlic they put in the garlic noodles it will keep away vampires, coworkers and boyfriends. Other then that I'm sure I will return...
author: Mae D.

description:
I'd heard from my waxing lady that this place had good food.  She's an SF native so I figured she'd know good Vietnamese food.  On her recommendation, my boyfriend and I went here for lunch last week.

(As a caveat, I didn't try the garlic noodles which everyone apparently LOVES.)

I got the 5-spice chicken rice meal and a side of stir fried vegetables.  The chicken was super fatty and not well spiced, the side of vegetables had little noodles in it which, whatever, but seems like you should list that in a menu for carb-concious folks.  My boyfriend got pork something that was pretty flavorful.  He said he would eat there again but with all of the goodness going on near 9th and Irving, I'm going to pass.
author: Rosie R.

description:
Perilla my most recent FIDI discovery.  Thank you Angelo F for the awesome lunchtime recommendation! 

The portions here are huge. I had the chicken curry and garlic noodles, Angelo F had the 5 Spice, and Theron L had the 5 Spice and veggies. All three meats were perfectly tender, juicy and very flavorful.  I prefer my curry a little richer (it was a bit watery) but it was still good.  I am for sure getting the pork next time!  Looked amazing. 

 Price wise, the lunch will run you $11.50--a tad pricey, but only a few dollars more than your boring lunchtime soup, sandwich or salad in the FIDI. The garlic noodles, to say the least, are powerfully pungent (but in a good garlicly way) ...so be sure to carry a couple packs of gum or a toothbrush. 

It gets very packed right at noon so I recommend leaving your office at 11:30pm.
author: Jessica G.

description:
I'd love to see a nifty pie chart of the various motivations that move folks to write Yelp reviews. Especially, reviews for places that have already racked up a shit load of reviews. 

I'm usually only motivated to write when I experience something unique and specific during my visit (good, bad, weird, funny etc.) so I'm going to bust out of my own personal pie slice and write about Perilla. 

That's correct, I'm writing because nothing of noteworthy excellence, vileness, oddness, or humor has transpired for me at Perilla. 

They do have this odd habit of NEVER bringing me my lemonade (and it's the GOOD kind of freshly made, ultra sour Vietnamese lemonade that makes my tongue and cheeks ache just thinking about it). This has happened so consistently I've given up ordering it (3 times in a row). Rather than get my panties in a bunch, I'm going to take this as a bit of Restaurant Parenting from the staff at Perilla. They're saying to me "Milk & Cheese, you don't need all that citric acid in the middle of your day, especially with all the greasy garlic noodles drowned in Rooster* sauce you're about to eat". 

Honestly, I wish more restaurants would take their parenting responsibilities more seriously. I like waiters with opinions. At least I like them right up till they veer into "fill your own damn water up" territory. 

Briefly: 
-the garlic noodles are too greasy and soft. Get the small order ($3.25) it's plenty 
-they either loath vegetables here or value them the way I value jeans that are comfortable without falling into "gangsta" territory, I wish they'd adopt a more Asia-esque veggies to meat-noodles ratio (say closer to 2 to 1 rather than the current 1 to 4) 
-way too crowded during the regular workdays lunch period (11:30-1ish) 

*Rooster sauce = Sriracha but I grew up calling it that because as a wee tot there was no way in hell I was going to wrap my gums around "sriracha". In fact, I'm not even doing it now, I'm typing "sriracha" but I'm internally verbalizing "rooster sauce". Yes, this does infer my baby bottle was full of rooster sauce.
author: Milk N.

description:
I'm so very sadden to have to do this but I have to give you 1 star.  Negative stars if I could!

I used to really like this restaurant but my disturbing experience today has changed my point of view entirely.  

I will NOT be going back.  Today I saw a huge tray of raw chicken laying on the ground.  On the dirty ground of the kitchen as staff steeped around it.  

Literally the chicken was exposed to the floor and feet.  There was no cling film.  The chicken was in a 1" deep dish!  REALLY?!!!  WTF!

I had already ordered.  When I stirred around the noodles, thankfully before I ate, there was a long pubic hair in my food!!!  SERIOUSLY!!!  WHAT THE HELL!!!! 

Both completely unacceptable!

NEVER GOING BACK!  I'd highly recommend you don't visit for your own good.  SO SAD!

If there was an additional tip it would be: DON'T GO!!!!
author: Marilyn K.

description:
This place is extremely popular at lunch.
I came here alone and ordered the spring rolls and chicken noodle soup. 

The second time I came I ordered with my friend.

Shrimp Sping rolls
Pork Spring Rolls
Chicken Bun
Beef with Garlic Noodles.

Fresh, fast friendly garlicky
Delicious.
author: Charlene C.

description: Really more like 3-1/2 stars.  So as everyone states here the Garlic Noodles are good however (spoiler alert) if you put anything in a crap load of Butter and Garlic ... it's likely to taste good.  I enjoyed the noodles but........I'd hate to know how many calories I just consumed.
author: Dyon Z.

description: Okay guys, so there are these garlic noodles but they aren't just ANY OLD BATCH of noodles.  Full-bodied, slick, and bitey, those garlic noodles elevate everything around them, be it of the cow or fowl variety.  And Perilla KNOWS how good they are because that's how they get YOU, the busy workaholic, to walk through the door; unabashed confidence in their cuisine.
author: Michael D.

description: Their garlic noodles are like crack. Once you've had them your hooked. These are the best I've had in SF.
author: J M.

description: Solid place, nearly as good as the sister restaurant in Sunset.  Had the papaya salad with beef and chicken garlic noodles, and the food was excellent as always.  Service was a bit slow, but it was a rainy day and the line was long, so it was to be expected.  Portion sizes were very large and plentiful (contrary to some reviews); I'm normally a voracious eater and was fully satiated with my food.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Since I am a wuss and don't like dark meat, I have since discovered TOFU cabbage salad- this salad takes me to my happy place when I am having a craptastic day.

ALSO they have Vietnamese Coffee!! Yaay for condensed milk and insanely caffeinated coffee- hot or iced, it's the best pick me up!
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
This is a great downtown lunch place!  The only downside is that it is very crowded and busy.  That being said, the wait is normally not too bad.

I had the garlic noodles and pork- it was delicious!!  And the prices are great.  I will definitely frequent this place now...
author: Alex R.

description:
Thank you Jason F for the awesome lunchtime recommendation! Prior to coming to Perilla I was stuck in a lunchtime rut--always ordering  from either Boudin's or SF Soup Co, brining it back to my office, and gobbling up a cobb salad or mexican tortilla soup whilst surfing the web.

The portions here are huge. I had the 5 spice chicken, Jason F had the charbroiled beef, and we made Angelo F order the pork. All three meats were perfectly tender, juicy and very flavorful. Price wise, the lunch will run you $11.50--a tad pricey, but only a few dollars more than your boring lunchtime soup, sandwich or salad. The garlic noodles, to say the least, are powerfully pungent (but in a good garlicly way) ...so be sure to carry a couple packs of gum or a toothbrush. FYI: After returning from lunch, my cube mates hinted at me that, ugh, my cube didn't smell too pleasant. I was known as the Gilroy garlic cube girl for the rest of the day...but at least no one stopped by my cube to bother me like they usually do...

PS: You have options FiDi Corporate Drones...you have options...so don't get stuck in a rut...
author: Sue L.

description:
A-OK indeed.

like a bikini wax, you don't care too much for the process, but rather, the results. 

quick, effective, and with a warm, full tummy as a result, Perilla delivered tasty, not entirely healthy vietnamese style food at your typical Fidi price. the five spice chicken was tasty, but greasy, and i did wish that there were more greens on my plate other than spring onion and two slices of cucumber. 

my coworkers loved the garlic noodles and boxed up their leftovers to go. a tad noisy, which makes me think that next time, i'll just box that up to go too.
author: Diana L.

description: So I was meeting a friend at SOMA and he wanted to go here. I knew it was going to be a rip off since I go to PPQ in the sunset and get the same for less. The food was good, but dude if we pay more why was my coffee size cut in half and charge me more, not cool. But food IS good.
author: Karen T.

description:
Lunch here was cheap, fast & a good break  from the ordinary salad/sandwiches/soups...blah blah dull bullshiets.

I had the pork chops along with the garlic noodles & the portions here are very generous for the $10 you pay. The noodles were good - not the best i've had, but it's really garlicky! LOVE it. The porkchops were juicy & really flavorful.

it's a clean vietnamese restaurant in the FIDI near work. On my list as one of my to go to lunch places whenever i'm in the mood for some vietnamese. Don't expect many options here because the menu is pretty short & simple - makes it super easy to order :)
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
I've been here a few times and have always enjoyed the food. This time (10/12) I went with 6 friends/co-workers. We got there around 11:30, so we beat the lunch crowd and were able to get 2 tables for ourselves. If you come here during peak lunch, expect to put your name on a list and wait 10 - 30 min.

I usually order the pork chops and garlic noodles, but decided to opt for the chicken curry and garlic noodles this time. The curry fell short of what I was expecting/hoping for. The sauce was very runny, which I did not care for, and it was not at all spicy as the menu had indicated. It also lacked flavor; it was rather bland for curry, but once I added my garlic noodles to it, it was a bit more tolerable.

I also ordered the imperial rolls for us. I haven't found imperial/spring rolls at a restaurant that even come close to my grandmother's, but thought the est of the group might enjoy them. I was not impressed with how they were served. You get the rolls and fish sauce and that's it; no lettuce and mints. I guess that's to be expected in the financial district. The rolls were very crispy and the filling was better than many other places.

Most of the others ordered five spice chicken with garlic noodles. I think the five spice chicken is their most popular item there and for good reason. It's super tasty. The flavor seems just right and the chicken is moist.

I still like their pork chop with garlic noodles best though; 3 juicy, flavorful pieces that remind me of how their like in Vietnam, except I get them over rice in Vietnam.

Vietnamese iced coffee is pretty darn good here. Nice and strong, but not too sweet. Everytime I've had it here it's made fresh to order. They drip it with the Vietnamese coffee filter behind the cashier and bring it to you when it's ready.

Service is sometimes fast and sometimes slow, it just depends. Depends on what? I don't know. I've been in here when there was just my table of 2 and 2 other tables and the service took forever. Then again, I've been in here when it's really packed and the service was surprisingly fast.

Anyhow, my 4 star rating is based off of my overall experience of this place including past visits.

Curry I would rate 2 stars. Imperial rolls 2.5 stars. Pork chops and five spice chicken get 5 stars.

Price seems a bit high, but the portions are pretty hefty, mostly b/c you get so much garlic noodles. You really could eat half now and half later. Must also take into account it's in the financial district.
author: Dennis Z.

description: Pawns rice dish was a mound of rice with only 7 small shrimp... not prawns... accompanied with 2 cold sprigs of broccoli. Pathetic. First time here and not returning.
author: Christopher K.

description: I didn't have the opportunity to dine here but I sure did the love the garlic noodles someone got for me. The garlic noodles are sooo good and very tasty. I can probably eat them everyday because they are sooo good.It so happens I like garlic. If you are not a fan of garlic I am sure you can find something else on the menu to taste.
author: Dani D.

description:
I was brought here by my co-worker for lunch coz we had a craving for garlic noodles. And damn, did this place hit the spot!

I had broiled pork (i think) with a side of garlic noodles. The noodles, although a little greasy for my taste, was awesome! 

BTW, I'm coming back today to get their five-spicy chicken with garlic noodles!
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
So, this little place isn't a real hardcore vietnamese place. It is a bit of a fusion like place. It has extremely limited selection, about 15 to 20 items. The items are standard vietnamese food such as grilled chicken, pork etc. What makes it slightly fusion is that you can get garlic noodles. That isn't standard in vietnamese food. It is more in viet/french food. If you don't want garlic noodles, you can get thins noodles.

There no soup here. One of the reasons I stop by here, was because I was looking for pho or something. Not present at this place. The prices are ok. I wouldn't want to pay that much though. Service is ok, and they are pretty quick.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
A decent sit down lunch in SF downtown for $10? I'd say that's a steal!!! If you are a carbophile, just get the BIG bowl of garlic noodles for $6.50. If you are a carb-conscious, this is not the right place for you. 

Three of us ate lunch here today. We ordered Imperial Rolls, Five Spice Chicken, Charbroiled Beef, and Charbroiled Shrimp. The Imperial Rolls were fantastic!!!! Thin, crispy skin and delicious and hot fillings. Mmmmmm.

The Five Spice Chicken was very delicious and flavorful. The chicken skin is so crispy. I thought it was good, and I hate dark meat! (Yes, they use dark meat for this dish. White meat doesn't even seem to be an option.) The Charbroiled shrimp was pretty good, too. However, the Charbroiled Beef was a bit disappointing. The quality of beef wasn't all that great. It was flavorless and not particularly tender. Portions for the meats are very limited. On the other hand, the garlic noodles that came with the meats could have been 3 separate meals for me. The plate also came with some broccoli. The Broccoli is a strange accompaniment. It's steamed plain broccoli with hoisin sauce that's been chilled. Why are they serving cold broccoli? I guess because it's cheap and easy.

Now on to the much talked about garlic noodles. Yes, you will stink all day. I brushed my teeth after I came back to the office, but the garlic breath is too potent to be quelled. And I'm sorry I drank a soda or two. The burping was lethal. :( 

My coworker came into my office and kept looking around and smelling her own shoes. She said something smelled strange and that she thought it was her shoes, she thought she stepped on something. I pretended that I didn't know what she was talking about and kept quiet. 

Smelly though it may be, the noodles are very tasty. It's a simple dish -  lots of garlic, butter, and chewy noodles. 

The service was very fast. Our water glasses were never empty. By noon, there was a long line of people waiting for a table. It gets crowded and very loud. I felt bad for people waiting for a table, so I wanted to eat fast and get out of there. Maybe next time I will sit away from the door, so I am not reminded of the people out the door. 

Well, we all liked the place very much and we think this will be our regular lunch spot. The food is good, it's close, and the price is right.
author: Su K.

description: I wish this placed delivered or at least had more space during lunch hour! good 5 spice chicken. go early or there's a line.
author: Emm C.

description: 5 Spice Chicken with Garlic Noodles! 'Nuff said!
author: Calvin L.

description:
along with everyones yelp reviews, i cam e to try this place. being the friday lunch hour i expected a wait. 15 minutes for 2 ppl wasn't too bad.

we ordered the garlic noodles, five spice chicken and a order of the beef spring rolls. garlic noodles are yummy. (i even saw a girl order just a bowl of the noodles), the five spice schicken didn't have enough five spice flavor but i did love how it was juicy and crispy to my liking. the beef spring rolls weren't one of my fav. i'll just come back for noodles and chicken.

I LIKE IT! this is my go-to spot.
author: KK M.

description: Never realized this place served asian food and they're the same owners at PPQ Dungeness Island. A friend was craving noodle soup and this popped up on yelp. Plus that it's close to our office, another plus that they serve you quickly and another plus for a good price that fills you up. I ended up getting the five spice chicken with garlic noodles. The noodles were al dente and definitely infused with garlic and butter. The chicken was flavorful and tender with a crispy skin.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Well the first thing first, Garlic noodles == amazing. Delicious noodles and with that great taste. I think I could probably eat these noodles without anything with them, of course the five spice chicken was good too. 

The only hard thing about this place is that its crowded! Oh god, so crowded, I just wanted to take out my food to eat someplace else and I was constantly playing move around so I don't hit the waiters. So if you're going to get take-out, here's a friendly hint, stand outside or something and just occasionally go and check in. There's a nice waiting area inside. They usually take a few minutes to make your food (if you're with a group they delivered it in batch, the guys who ordered pork first and then we got our five spice chicken later) so I assume they make the meat and noodles in large quantities and just combine them later.
author: Rohan D.

description: Garlic noodles with beef. Holy crap. Very garlicky and buttery just how I like it, and they weren't overcooked. The beef was also really tender and juicy.  Portions are amazing so that even my legendary appetite couldn't polish off an entire plate. Apparently everything here is good though, so I'll have to come back and try some of their other dishes!
author: Julie C.

description:
I've had my eye on you! I've been passing by this place whenever I walk to other eateries for lunch and I saw the menu and read "Garlic Noodles" "Five Spice Chicken" and my brain on auto pilot thought "Hmm.. is this a PPQ owned joint?" 

Today, I gave it a go and after seeing a familiar face welcoming me in to the building... I was assured that this was a PPQ establishment (they also handle Toasties: aka the best crab melt ever). 

Their menu is simple, some salads and starters, then plates with the protein, veggie and noodle. I got the five spice plate with garlic noodles and it came out to $10. It's a tad overpriced for everyday lunching, but for PPQ goodness, you pay for it. 

The noodles were totally remnicent of PPQ's as was the chicken. 

I think the next time I crave noodles, I'll order their heaping bowl which is about $6.50.  A side is $3.5 but I have no clue how big that is.

It's great to have the goodness of PPQ right around the corner.. but I am sad there's no crab, or crab type of dish on the menu.  I think I should stock up on some gum because the breath will be Garlic all day long.
author: Alyson C.

description: Good Delicious Garlic Noodles. The staff were really nice too. Had their five-spice chicken w/ garlic noodles and imperial rolls both times and it hit the spot.
author: Tim F.

description: When I pay $11 for chicken curry noodle soup, I expect HIGH QUALITY WHITE MEAT CHICKEN.  Here I got huge fatty, low quality, dark meat in my soup.  Not only was it all dark meat, the pieces were WAY too big for soup.  GROSS!  But, the broth was good.  Too bad - I was looking forward to finding high quality chicken here.
author: JM H.

description: Insanely busy (hard to have a conversation) but the food was affordable and tasty - I enjoyed my lemon grass beef plate!
author: Emily M.

description: This place is excellent. My friend had the Five Spice Chicken Garlic Noodle and I had the Chicken Curry Garlic Noodle. You could smell the Garlic Noodles when the waitress was about 5 feet away and boy did it smell amazing! Once I dipped the chicken into the noodles and took a bite, I was impressed (I forgot to add there was definitely some Sriracha added on my behalf). Then I tried the Five Spice Chicken and it was even better! I recommend this place, for sure.
author: Corey R.

description:
Came here the other day for lunch after Chris G. said people had been raving about it. At first we were deterred due to passing the sign in list (five people signed up in the minute it took us to realize that there was a list...doh!)

Fortunately, the tables turn fast here and boy were we glad that we waited the 6 minutes it took to be seated. The garlic noodles and beef dish was heavenly. I would highly recommend this place. Good service as well. 

Out The Door at the Westfiled Center, you can shove it!
author: Jackie M.

description: OMG, amazing garlic noodles!  Even though they are supposed to be open at 10:30, they really aren't ready by then.  I can call to place my order at 10:30, they'll tell me it's ready in 15, I'll show up and still wait another 5-10 mins.  Oh wells, it's not like I want to stay in the office the whole time.  Was bummed when they raised their prices a month ago...each entree went up by almost a buck.  Alas, I'll continue to get the garlic noodles once a week because it's OH SO GOOD!  I like the garlic noodles with pork.
author: B C.

description:
Shrimp Rolls: $6 for 3, cut in to 2 pieces each.  $1 for each section.
Big Honking Bowl of Garlic Noodles: $6.50.  Not bad
5 Spice Chicken Salad made up of mostly cabbage and fried onion and the smallest, tinniest, shriveled up looking Imperial Roll: $8 or $9.
Total Bill: $24.09.

Leslie and I were really really full.  Which was a good thing.  Because if we'd spent $24.09 at a proper Vietnamese place and were not completely full, I would kill someone.  Or start my diet.  Prolly the former.  

Garlic Noodles: not bad.  I could see the pieces of garlic.  It did not have that intense buttery flavor, nor the overwhelming infusion of garlic.  I would have added the garlic last to the noodles in order to preserve that strong spicy garlic smell.

This is the first time i've had 5 spice chicken at a restaurant.  Therefore it's not entirely new.  But it didn't quite taste quite right.  I think they were skimpy on the chicken and heavy on the cabbage, plus too much sugar in the dressing.  Afterwards, I was WIRED but bloated.  Such a strange sensation.  The Imperial Roll required being put out of it's misery.  It had no more will to live.  It was barely in existence.

The shrimp rolls . . . were . . . small, though fresh.  There was about half a shrimp per section.  Those cheap bastards.  And they cost a fortune.  I don't know what to think about them.  I think they were under the radar.  The only think mentionable about them was the price.  $6.  For shirmp Rolls.  

This place is really close to school.  After the lunch rush, it dies down and there are empty seats and tables.  I will not come here willingly, it was only because Leslie kicked my little asian tush in Oral Arguments and I felt obliged.  Grr.  Oral Arguments.  Also, they do not have pho.  Or pad thai.  Most of the round eyes (and even the slanty eyed) ordered the meat-plus-two-veg-and noodle plate or the meat-plus-two-veg and rice plate.  They have about 8 things on the menu, all expensive for Vietnamese standards.  And the Thai iced tea had a day-glo orange color.  

I need some caffeine now.

(punctuations cost extra today so I'm using them sparingly)
author: Christina C.

description: My fave garlic noodles in the world! W/ pork! Yumm! Only thing... sooo PRICEY!!! C'mon, noodles are SOOO cheap! Why'd you feel the need to raise the price. My wallet!
author: Alicia D.

description:
A prime spot for the FiDi crowd who like cheap eats (in comparison to the other options in the area), hearty tasty food and sizable portions.  I always get the 5 spice chicken and garlic noodles which puts me back about $10.  The chicken is moist and juicy but the best part is the crispy skin.  The pork is also good.  Thai tea is good.  Everyone has their preferences for meat but the most important thing to remember is that it's all about the garlic noodles.  Garlicky, buttery noodles... mmm....  if you're watching your carb intake, stay away from this place.

-12-1 is the lunch rush.  Come by 11:45 or after the end of the lunch rush or else you'll wait forever for a table.
author: Justine L.

description: What a rip off!! I ordered the chicken and noodle and it costed $11!! The food isnt even great. It just editble. It's sooo westernized. I would have giving 3 stars but the food is way overpriced.
author: Ricki H.

description:
After a lunch here I could slay dragons with one calculated burst of post garlic noodle breath. For the best outcome, play the roles of Lady and the Tramp in which two parties slurp one end of a long strand before engaging in a extended tonsil hockey so pheromones fill the air and both fail to notice the sweet stench emanating from their pores. Or if you're peeved at your housemate/co-workers for stray teabags on counters or using an outside voice when talking on the phone, a helping of this and kindly conversation is an effective, polite way of saying, "eat a dick." 

I'm kidding, mostly.

Regardless, you needn't be afraid because though these are the same folks that brought us PPQ, the garlic is far less pungent (read: not fresh). Still the grilled meats served up with a requisite broccoli bush prove tasty and reasonable. For those who prefer to leave creatures unharmed, the veggie dishes are satisfying, replete with mushrooms, cabbage and carrots - and both come with magical piles of none-too-greasy noodles on the cheap.

You'll find me here often. Clear the way.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
