I'm a little confused by the pho-tos and some of the earlier reviews about Perilla that say they serve pho. Maybe they did when they first opened? Unfortunately, they don't have any pho on their menu anymore. It's also rumored that Perilla is from the people behind PPQ, one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the city. No dungeness crab here though!

Nonetheless, the entrees here are pretty solid. You get a choice of rice or garlic noodles on the side. Everything on their pretty straight forward menu is between $6-10, which is makes it into my regular work lunch rotation.

The jumbo tiger prawns are really good, as is their five spice chicken and veggie & tofu. 

Now, if they added pho to their menu, I'd be here a lot more. Pho on rainy days is the pho-king best.
author: Connie C.

description:
From the people who brought you horrendously bad garlic breath in the form of delicious noodleage at PPQ, comes the much closer to work and no need for a long ass bus ride to the Richmond... Perilla. 

I have begun what will now be referred to as, "THE FALL WHERE STEPHY LOST 20 LBS!!!!!!!" It isn't going to be easy. It isn't going to be fun. But what will be fun is looking like I feel on the inside and actually fitting back into my clothes. And so, as a way to kick start this project, I joined Weight Watchers. Yep. Weight Watchers. I figured points and food could live harmoniously together and perhaps there is something to this counting your food and portion control.

As a way to test it out in the real world, I figured if I couldn't go to a lunch and order something and still make the point count, then maybe this plan isn't for me. And so, we ordered the vegetables, the garlic noodles and the 5 spice fried chicken (don't worry, i peeled the skin off... that deep, dark, deliciously crispy, yum in your mouth skin). I only ate about 1/4 of my food and only had a few bites of the noodles and after coming back to the office and inputting the food I ate, and even doubling the points as my friend suggested, I still have 11 whoppin' points left for the day.

And so, tonight I get to look forward to one or two grapes, a cracker and 14 gallons of water. Oh the joys of getting thinner.
author: Stephy S.

description:
There's something about fishing around in a big bowl for hunks o' meat with chopsticks that relaxes me. Call me a weirdo, but FiDi lunch options can get a little stale sometimes. That's where pho comes in.

When I heard about Perilla, I got all excited. I was expecting a hole in the wall, but the interior was so warm and cute and clean we decided to take a seat and make a date out of it. Actually getting a seat proved to be a little challenging, and the restaurant seemed understaffed, but I assume they're just working out some kinks.

I ordered the charbroiled pork with vermicelli and Jessica ordered the grilled shrimp. Yummm! I was especially impressed with the shrimp, which was big and fresh and grilled to perfection. $8 is a little pricey, but the bowl was big and I was still working on it the next day.

Very solid lunch option. I'll be back, pho sho!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Unless you want to watch people eating good food from outside the windows, get here early before the lunch crowd.

If you love great great food at a low low price, then this is the spot!  The dishes are all around the $10 range and you get a plate full.  Chelle had the 5 spice chicken with garlic noodles, RJ had the charbroiled beef with garlic noodles and I had the charbroiled pork with garlic noodles and we all shared the imperial rolls.  I knew I was gonna love this place as soon as I walked in the doors and was hit by that undeniable garlic noodle smell.  

I'm so hungry now thinking about this place, I think I'm going to have to send someone here today for a lunch pick up!
author: Myke Y.

description:
I was bored and Perilla came to my rescue by saving me from the monotony of the usual sandwich/salad/soup lunch routine. What's not to love about a giant, heaping pile of GARLIC NOODLES, accompanied by a side of five spice chicken? Nomnomnom. You also can't go wrong with the beef or the bbq pork, which are both tasty. The alternatives to the garlic noodles are either the vermicelli or rice, but I'd definitely recommend the garlic noodles. Vegetarians, fret not, they do have a veggie option to accompany the noodles.

Perilla has seating for dining in, or you can take out and go back to your office, but either way service is fast. Portions are very generous and keep you filled up through the rest of the work day. The only downside? $9-$12 is a tad pricier for this type of food, which you could easily get for less if you weren't in the SOMA working district. But the portion size makes up for it, and really, my mouth is too full of delicious, buttery garlic noodles to be complaining. Nomnomnomnom.
author: Felicia C.

description: Love this place.  It is near where I work, and so convenient.  Their five spice chicken is delicious!  Also their chicken noodle soup.  Though I almost exclusively go for take out.  If you want to have a sit down meal, prepare to come early, or wait a bit for a table.  Don't forget to try their garlic noodles.  YUM YUM!
author: Lori H.

description:
After experiencing the lousy service and expensive pho at Pho Hoa in the Embarcadero, I was jumping with Glee when Perilla opened up. 

Unfortunately, all Perilla's Pho dishes has rare beef. And I was in one of those moods that my close friends call "I can't eat beef moods". 
Meaning I started questioning. I questioned where do they get their beef?  Were the cows grass fed and roamed happily in Marin or Sonoma County? Or were they left to waste in slaughterhouse conditions? Am I gonna digest  hormones pumped into cattle and become a big fat pregnant-like cow spilling milk out for America? 
You know, THAT MOOD.

So,  I decided on the Charbroiled Tiger Prawns marinated in Garlic with vermicelli. 

Waiting.
Talking.
Glance around for the food.
Waiting.
Talking.
Glance around for the food.
*REPEAT the above for 20 minutes* 
This is a long time for waiting when you are on your lunch hour. 

Finally, the dishes are placed in front of us. 
Appearance test - Pass.
Breathe in.
Smell test - Ok, I'll pass it.
Taste test....bleh. bleh. bleh. The noodles stuck together. However, the shrimp was tasty. Score a point!

The Spring Rolls ($6), which happens to be the APPETIZER for the table finally arrived. YES, after the entrees. They were fresh but filled with vermicelli instead of the good stuff like vegetables or your choice meat. In this case, shrimp. Yeah, my co-workers put up with me and my no eat red meat moods. They all had some type of beef as their entree. Anyhow, due to the overwhelming amount of vermicelli...the spring rolls were bland, bland, bland.

One of my co-workers is a certified Vietnamese male. Certified meaning he was born in Vietnam and still speaks the language. Note: Man of few words. He said "Don't bring me back here." Well, ok then. Tell me how you really feel.

Overall: BAD bad service, food was ok, place was extremely clean, nice decor...though, would hate to get slammed up again the brick walls. Don't know why that would happen...I'm only saying.

Will come back if you ask me to.
author: Liz K.

description:
Very nice and cozy restaurant - don't be fooled by the lines because the wait is often short and the service is quick. I went in at 1:00 and we had no problem getting a table.

The portions are decent and the food is good. We had the BBQ pork and the Five spice chicken, all of which were very tender and well marinated. 

Service was quick and attentive. Perfect lunch spot for those of us on the go.
author: Candy C.

description:
A new Vietnamese restaurant! AND I love it! Owned by the PPQ owners, you know their food is gonna be excellent. Located in the Mission, I wish it would of been closer to me... Lucky ass FIDI people!!!! But I guess I can travel to get my Perilla fix.

My friend and I went there for lunch yesterday around 1230ish and it was packed. Line was out the door and continued being like that til around 2? The restaurant wasn't the biggest but was pretty spacious. 

Their menu option is not as big as a lot of the other Vietnamese places but this is a more upscale place. They offer Carpaccio (Bo Tai Chanh), Papaya salads, a couple options in Pho, rice and vermicelli plates.

My friend and I ordered the:
Carpaccio ($13)- Rare thinly sliced Angus beef flank in lemon vinaigrette with basil, red onions, peanuts and fried shallots served with a jalapeno fish sauce.  
     I thought this was really good. It wasn't the typical slice flat beef placed on the plate. It's more like clumps of yummy rare beef over a salad. If you were to mix everything, it would be a salad. Really good but a little expensive.
Perilla Combo ($8.5)- Rare Angus flank,  well-done Angus brisket and meatball. 
    Usually when you order this at other restaurants, for the price you get a lot more BUT, this is the FIDI and this place is more upscale. I didn't eat this but friend did and he said it was one of the best pho he's had..
Five Spice Chicken with rice ($7.5)- WOW. The chicken is so damn good! I love how they made the skin so crispy! It was like heaven in a piece of chicken. Big portion of rice and served with broccoli. You can also substitute rice or vermicelli with pho or garlic noodle for $1.50 more.
Garlic Noodles (6.5)- Buttery, garlicky, and yummy
Thai Iced Tea (2.5)-So good!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I saw a lot of people order this so you should too!

Service couldn't of been better. Always attentive and friendly
author: Juliane N.

description: The food was alright. This was my first time eating garlic noodles. They were too greasy, and I felt gross for the rest of the day. The chicken was good tho. Not worth the price in my opinion. Definitely comfort food, but not what I would eat on a lunch break from work where people won't want to smell your garlic breath.
author: Max M.

description: My takeout was ready within five minutes as promised. I ordered the five spice chicken vermicelli bowl. It was nothing to write home about, but good. A-Ok.
author: Olivia P.

description: This place is really all about the garlic noodles.  Of course, it seems garlic noodles aren't really a traditional Vietnamese dish, but who cares?  That is, I've asked for something similar at other Vietnamese places and they have no idea what I'm talking about.  So, I guess I just have to go to Perilla to get my fix.  But, since I work like two buildings away, that's not so hard to accomplish.  Try the garlic noodles with whatever meat sounds good to you.  I like the five-spice chicken or the pork, but sometimes get just the noodles on their own if I want a lighter meal.  Anyhow, go.  And don't be intimidated by the long line at lunch time--it goes pretty fast and once you sit down and order, you have food in like three minutes.
author: Dave B.

description:
I always hesitate before trying nice-looking Vietnamese/Chinese Places, because that somehow always sets off my "White-washed Asian Food" radar.  But this place has won my respect.  I can't say this is authentic Vietnamese cuisine, but it's definitely tworth a try for those with similarly unforgiving radars.

Great BBQ meats (I tried pork and beef, both very flavorful and tender) and make sure you try their garlic noodle even though it's $1.50 extra.  I don't know how their pho is though I doubt I would try it when I know their meat and noodle dishes are super yummy (don't hate me for not wanting to wait 30 min for a bowl of pho... even if it's like pho-king amazing pho... *haha kneeslapper* -_- )... but ya it's good, just try it :p
author: Angela H.

description:
Hats off to the folks at PPQ for bringing their specialty to hungry lunchers in the Financial District!  Finally...we don't have to pay those outrageous prices for that other place in the Embarcadero, or trek our way up to Chinatown for a decent bowl of pho.  It is still fairly expensive - about a dollar more per bowl than elsewhere, and there is only one size.  The soup is a bit bland, and the bowls don't hold enough soup so that you better eat your pho fast or else the noodles will soak up all the soup.  Their garlic noodles are reminiscent of the ones at the other location, but for some reason they just don't taste as good.  I think maybe it's missing the crab juice?  

All in all, a very fair substitution for your Vietnamese fix for lunch.  I'm a fan purely because there is no better place in its area.  Smart move, PPQ folks!
author: Liz C.

description: The garlic noodles here are pretty good. It's very very garlicky tho, so beware of having garlic breathe for the rest of the day. I got the five spice chicken and the chicken was pretty tender and juicy :) I only got 2 pieces of broccoli with my food...wish I got more veggies. I like eating a balanced diet.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
My gal pal and I had lunch here today since I was in the area...and I'd definitely come back!

I was craving spring rolls with peanut sauce, so I ordered the shrimp rolls, which of course came with peanut sauce.  My friend ordered the beef rolls which were fried.

We also ordered the grilled beef with a side of garlic noodles.  Both were very delicious!  

Total bill came out to about $26 which we split down the middle.  Very reasonably priced for the quality of the food and the attentive service.

It can get busy during lunchtime so be prepared to wait about 10 to 15 minutes for a table.
author: Christine E.

description:
Went last week with a friend of mine - we're always looking for the next best lunch place.  We usually eat in the Richmond or the Marina, but last week we had time to go downtown.  Heard about Perilla's from my friend at Toasties (sandwich place at 10th/Irving).  The owner also runs Perilla's.  

We had the Beef Papaya Salad, Charbroiled Pork Chop & the Charbroiled Pork - both with garlic noodles.  A self professed pig, I couldn't believe I couldn't finish my food and had to doggy bag it!  In other words - really LARGE portions.  May I remind you there is nothing better than leftover garlic noodles while coach potato-ing it!

The fish sauce that came with both the salad and the entree's, was mighty tasty and I wanted to drink it straight out of the cup - maybe next time when I take it to go....

The meat on all the dishes were tender, hot, yummy and well cooked.  The service was friendly, though the language limitations were pretty funny.  I talk too fast but thankfully the order was taken perfectly.  

The tab came out to $31 for the three dishes, a drink and iced coffee.  Very well priced and quick table service.  Was dreaming about garlic noodles the next night - good sign to go back ... OFTEN!
author: Eileen A.

description:
Today was my first time at Perilla.  I ended up having to sit at the edge of a table for 4--at first the waitress didn't want to sit me there because it would be blocking the aisle.  She finally decided it was ok because I was skinny...lol.  Being that I arrived later than my 4 other friends, they got my food out really quick.

I must say though, the garlic noodles weren't that tasty.  The beef was generous and the broccoli was really cold!  I couldn't imagine how this would cost more than $8 so I was surprised to see it costed $10.50.

Because I was the end seat I had to get out of my seat a total of 3 times so that the noodle delivery guy could ge through.  They were all really apologetic but the third time it started to get annoying.  I guess that's what I get for showing up late.

Maybe it's worth it going back and trying something else...because what I ordered was just so-so.
author: Christopher W.

description:
CHARGE ME $1.50 for a CHEAPIE TEA BAG????? 

That's right. I can buy a whole box of tea, for the price of the teabag.  Chris and I ordered an imperial roll, he had the chicken dish with rice, I had the beef with the garlic noodles.  The rolls, burnt. The beef, chewy. The broccoli, SUPER underdone. The noodles... raw. The tea, worth about the same as a non-existant payphone in the city. The chicken... not bad. 

Um. At least I have more Asian options now?
author: Lisa L.

description:
Went here on the advice of fellow Yelpers.   Place was PACKED at lunchtime and had to wait for a little while but nothing major.   Ordered the Garlic Noodles w/ 5 Spice Chicken.    Plate came out piled high with thick yummy pan fried noodles that tasted about what I expected.   Very good but not great.     The chicken was the real surprise.   A whole breast with skin on cooked to juicy and crispy perfection...of course with a nice five spice all over.

Service was good for a place so busy and it seemed clean enough.    I'll for sure be going back.
author: Dave P.

description: Simply put - mediocre food and service that rushes you. The noodles with seasoned vegetables were just a pile of plain-tasting noodles with cabbage, nothing to write home about . The waiter began making pointed requests for our check at 12:35 - I understand it's lunch rush, but I feel like a table for a few diners at noon should be ours for an hour without being hassled.
author: Chris B.

description:
During our boba break at Tea Garden, my girl friends and I noticed a big 8.08.08 grand opening sign and a long line across the street.  When we learned it was a new Vietnamese restaurant, we pledged to come back to try it.  

We came early for lunch to beat the crowds.  I was pretty surprised to see there was no pho on the menu, but I was happy with how you could customize your entree.  You pick your meat entree (beef, shrimp, five-spice chicken, pork) and then whether you wanted it over rice, vermicelli, or garlic noodles.  Plus, they added an asterisk for dishes with peanuts which is very considerate for those of us with food allergies!  I tried the imperial rolls as an appetizer and the lemongrass beef over rice.  The beef was excellent and very tender. 

With the great food, reasonable prices and convenient location, I can now add Vietnamese food into my weekday lunch rotation without the hike to Chinatown!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
I always welcome variety in ethnic cuisine lunch spots in the no man's land area below Market street that is still "financial district."  Am happy to try Perilla for lunch today.  The name is a little esoteric since nobody is going to get it unless they are familiar with Vietnamese mint varieties.  Not a typical Viet restaurant name.  However, am glad to see that they serve fish sauce as dipping for their vermicelli bowls.  The BBQ beef is a little rare, which is fine with me but might scare the squirmish.  Also, a "true" vermicelli bowl would have spring rolls and some other added stuff.  Overall, not the most amazing BBQ beef vermicelli I've had, but it satisfies my tummy and palate.

Add'l tips: come before 11:30AM or after 1PM, as the place gets packed.  I came at 11:30AM and got seated, ate, paid, and left before 12 noon.
author: Renee K.

description:
When you're out with your coworkers, the typical fidi lunch goes as follows - you all sit down, order an entree, you eat it then you pay at the front all in an effort to save some time.  We went here during lunch at work and one guy from another group designed to join.  We all ordered entrees and when the waitress got to this guy he was like "in addition to my entree, I would like a side salad and thai iced tea."  After we were all done eating, he was like.."OK should we split the bill evenly?"  Honestly dude?!?! I mean, you're probably making more money than me already and you wanna play a gyp on me like that?!!? bastard!  You know what the shitty part is, his portion comes out to like...$3 more a person so it's not like its enough to really make a big fuss, just freakin annoying...

This place used to be a crap shoot of a Chinese restaurant, but now they've redone it inside so it's very modern looking yet it's got brick walls to know they're keeping it real.  They're also keeping the food real here too;  their menu is pretty standard - cold noodle dishes with various proteins and salads with some out of the ordinary toppings.  I got grilled chicken with garlic noodles and it was absolutely awesome!  The chicken was cooked VERY well - skin on, but crispy and not oily.  The garlic noodles were kick - ass tasty; though my breath was probably strong enough to knock Oscar De La Hoya down (though these days it looks like Stephen Hawkins could beat him in a fistfight).  My coworkers got the cold vermecelli and it looked awesome as well.  Great Vietnamese food without cockroaches on the floor or gum on the walls?!?! Yes!
author: Nico M.

description:
I read the Yelp reviews prior to going to Perilla today and took on the recommendation of the Beef and Garlic Noodles.  I must say it was actually pretty decent and I was surprised at how packed the place gets after 12.  The beef was very tender, perfectly cooked and seasoned, and went nicely with the accompanied fish sauce on the plate.  I must agree with other reviewers that the vegetables that come on the plate, partially steamed brocolli, with hoysien sauce, was not that appetizing although edible.

Also the garlic noodles weren't THAT bad.  I really don't see the fuss about Thanh long's noodles to these.  Thanh Long really isn't that great especially for how much you pay for crab when you can get it for much cheaper in Chinese restaurants without the overwhelming taste of butter in your mouth but I digress this review is about Perilla.

We got there early enough to fit a table for 6, the food came to our table quickly and was DEEEE licious....well in the sense that we don't really have that many decent Vietnamese places close to work other than Slanted Door (which personally I don't think is all that decent and is too expensive).  

Hands Down I will definitely be coming back here again and if it's after 12 I will call ahead to get it to go.  Be forewarned that a line will snake through the restaurant when it gets really busy for people that decide to do take out instead of waiting to eat in.
author: grace m.

description: A little more than I like to spend but I can get two meals out of it (lunch and leftovers for dinner). 5-Spice Chicken with Garlic Noodles - not as good as my friend makes but definitely good. Down a star because it's not that big a space, lines form quickly and ah-hem, yes, I'm talking to you, who cuts in line, writes their name on the sheet at the bottom of the page rather than going under my name in the next column and taking my table by the window after I was waiting 15 minutes and you arrived 10 after me. Not cool lady, not cool.
author: VeryBerry F.

description:
What a nice change of pace from the usual "organic" salads and sandwiches in FiDi. 

This place is basically like a mini version of Unicorn but a little less greasy. Fast Vietnamese styled rice/noodle dishes, well-seasoned, huge portions and yummy garlic noodles. Reasonable prices at $8-$10 an entree. 

Does get very crowded so go early, like at 11:30am.
author: Veronica S.

description: Their pork chop and five spice chicken are pretty good. The garlic noodle is ok. I can make that at home. I gave 2 star because their kitchen is pretty dirty. There were trays of meat on the kitchen floor where customer can see it when standing in front of the cashier! How can they pass health department inspection?
author: Vivi C.

description:
I'm pretty sure "garlic noodles" are not a real Vietnamese thing (my parents are from Vietnam and have never heard of such a thing), but whatever, they are yummy.  I got the 5 spice chicken and that was pretty good as well.  Tender, well-seasoned, quality dark meat (white meat is for suckers).  

There were several parties in line when I arrived and it looked fairly busy, but I got a table surprisingly quickly (maybe 5 minutes).  Service is friendly and prompt.  

The only thing is - $10 for chicken and garlic noodles?  You do get a fair amount of food (I had enough leftover for a smaller 2nd course), but still.  If it were a few dollars cheaper, I'd come a lot more often.  Tasty food, though, if not exactly authentic.
author: Leslie L.

description: Order the 5 spice chicken! It'll hit the spot. It's juicy plus the skin was nice and crispy the way it should be and I'm usually not a fan of chicken skin. We also tried the imperial rolls, yum. Can't go wrong with anything fried right? Couldn't try the garlic noodles this visit because of a meeting but it's mos def on my eat list. Big portions so come with an appetite and come no later than 11:30 if u don't want to wait.
author: T L.

description:
The dishes are large and tasty. I've been there three times. The third time they RAN OUT OF RICE before it was even 12:00 PM. Two of the three of us in my party were craving rice with hot food. The rice noodles are cold. The garlic noodles are okay, but too much raw garlic, not cooked well enough. 

Service is pretty quick. If you know the times to go, you should go before and after the rush hour. Five minutes will make a difference.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
I love ... like majorly love ... good cheap eats.  This place would be right up Rachel Ray's alley, and I mean that in a good way.  

If you're looking for a quick, hearty and delicious lunchtime spot, this is the place.  I have severe peanut allergies so my menu selections are a bit limited, but I highly recommend the shrimp with garlic noodles ... its divine.  While the service can be a bit brusque, the price and quality of the food more than make up for it.  If this place was any closer to my office I would go everyday.
author: Sho O.

description:
To satisfy a friend's demand for Vietnamese fare in the SOMA area, I brought him to Perilla based on Yelp's reviews.  I had never ate at Perilla's.  Everytime I walked by to grab a meal at Portico, the wait line for Perilla was out the door.

Anyhow, we arrived at 12 sharp and was seated at 12:10. Initially, I thought it would have been a longer wait.  We came in a group of three and I noticed many of the tables seated just two.  We lucked out as a few groups at the larger tables were finishing up.

I already knew what I wanted to order based on Yelp reviews, the Five Spice Chicken Garlic Noodles.  It did not disappoint. The noodles were very garlic-y and just the right texture.  The meat was well-prepared and the skin crisp.  There was a little bit more fat than I expected, but no biggie.

The meal was fairly priced for the area, especially for a sit-in type restaurant.

Will visit again if my craving for garlic noodles acts up.
author: S N.

description:
I've been apologizing for my breath two days in a row thanks to Perilla's garlic noodles. Not even Orbit could clean the dirty up.

Today I thought, hmmm maybe Thai? But when push came to shove, the garlic noodles were on line two of ext. 2233 saying, "Hello? EAT ME. And I'll be ready in 10. K. Thx. Bye. Oh, and screw your co-workers, garlic is in baby."

Grilled Pork: Yup, really juicy good.
Grilled Shrimp: Yup, tasty.
Grilled anything from here is a sure bet, pile on those garlic noodles!

I'll be a regular Perilla!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Craving some garlic noodles and looked up this place... satisfied my craving and more!

I ordered the five spice chicken with garlic noodles and it came out to $10... I've been to a lot of cheap Vietnamese places, so this was on the mid-price tier... not super fancy like Than Long or PPQ but not super hole-in-the-wall like Sunflower.    

FOOD:  My garlic noodles hit the spot.. good noodle texture, nice and garlic-y but not overly oily.   The five spice chicken was tender and tasty although they could be a bit more generous with the chicken and the 6 pieces of string beans that they give you on the side.   

I ordered takeout and the service was good... no big complaints but what could I expect for being in the restaurant for 5 minutes to pick up food.  

Decor:  place is clean and has some subtle decorations.    

I'll definitely be back...
author: T M.

description: I love garlic so it makes sense why I like this place. The garlic noodles are great and at a very decent price. This place does tend to get very very busy so expect a bit of a wait if you come during peak hours.
author: Danny C.

description:
I had take out charbroiled pork today with garlic noodles.  The pork tasted great but it REALLY appeared to be beef.  Visually beef has a certain appearance.  I enjoyed dipping the "pork" into a sweet dipping sauce they provided.  There was also soy sauce and hot sauce provided in little containers.  The meat and noodles were warm which is good.  Unfortunately, the brocolli was cold.  It did have that nice cooked look to it that signified that previously it was properly cooked ( nice crunch to it ).

This was a nice diversion from my usual lunch fare.

3 1/2 stars.
author: Robert C.

description:
The best time to come in during the weekdays for lunch would be after 1pm.
The garlic noodles were cooked perfectly and were very buttery and delicious. You get a very hefty portion when you order them, you can actually taste the garlic, and they go great alongside any meat or veggie combo.
The 5-spice chicken was crispy on the outside and tender, juicy and flavorful on the inside.   The service was excellent and they definitely make sure  your glass is full!
author: B W.

description:
Oh my god, does everyone's breath smells now! However, it was well worth it in my mind. After hearing about the garlic noodle and smelling it for days from my coworker, today was the day to give this place a try.

3 of us went to the restaurant at 11:45am, trying to beat the line. Lo and behold, the line was out the door once we were seated. We ordered pork chop, beef, and 5-spice chicken with garlic noodle. Service was a bit slow, as we went into an awkward silence after some casual chatter... After about 10 minutes, our garliky food arrived! The noodle was chewy and flavourful, my chicken was juicy with some crispy skin bits (droolz...) Coworkers were happy about their selections too.

I don't know how authentic garlic noodle is in Vietnamese cuisine, but this restaurant definitely got onto my lunch list. The prices are high though, can't really expect people to spend $12 per person for lunch... We might come back once in a few months.
author: Lois W.

description: Went with a co-worker who recommended we get there before 12noon.  Smart idea.  Got there at 11:30 and no crowd.  By 12noon the line was outside.  I had the pork vermicelli.  Good portion and very tasty meat.  Very simple menu and the chicken and beef both look good.  If you sit in and dine it's $10.  If you get takeout, it's $8.  About one to two dollars more than regular Vietnamese places, but downtown FIDI.
author: Josh L.

description:
Well, the service is as cold, rushed, and unpleasant as ever, but the food seems to have slipped a notch the last couple of times I've been in. The barbecued beef, which used to be lovely, has been coming out of the kitchen cold and greasy of late.

The food's lost a couple of its stars now. We won't be back.
author: David G.

description:
I'm a sucker for anything with garlic, so the first thing I tried was the Charbroiled Shrimp with Garlic Noodles.  The shrimp was good, with a nice char to the surface.  The noodles were okay - slightly softer than al dente but packed with minced garlic (mmm!!)

My friend and I split the Spring Rolls, which I agree with some other reviewers were standard fare.  The dipping sauce was mild.  I prefer spicy, but I guess I should have asked for spicy sauce.. Always remember, if you want spicy then ask for spicy!  This holds true for any restaurant.

Come very early or arrive late (that's what we did) to avoid the lunch rush.  It makes a huge difference when you decide to dine in here.
author: Eileen P.

description: I went to this price with a few coworkers, and I was impressed with the taste. This place is nothing like the traditional Vienamese fur place in the taste department. Price is about normal, considering it is located in financial district. The only problem is that if you go around 12pm, the waiting list is really long. 11:30pm is a more reasonable time to be there.
author: Jun W.

description:
Awesome garlic noodles!  So far I only tried the charbroiled pork and it's juicy and has a nice charbroiled flavor.  A little on the thin side though, but the flavor makes up for it.  Average price $9-12.

I wouldn't get the imperial roll on the side though because they are small and very skinny, not worth the extra $2.

Restaurant setting is nice.  You have to go before 1145 in order to not have a long wait.  This place gets packed during lunch.

It's great to get some decent Vietnamese food in financial district at a reasonable price.  I think I will be a frequent customer!
author: Yun W.

description:
I just have to give this place 5 stars for their garlic noodles. A coworker showed me this place and I'm addicted. I've tried the 5 spice chicken and the BBQ pork. Both meats are great, but i really only come for the garlic noodles. 

Did i say that the garlic noodles are great? Yeah. the Garlic Noodles are GREAT!!!!
author: J-nine I.

description:
When I crave for garlic noodles and five spice chicken, I would come to Perrilla. However after what I saw today, I am not coming back.

Today, my friend and I went to Perrilla and as we were waiting for our order, we saw one of the cooks marinating chicken on the kitchen floor. And then, he dropped a couple of pieces of chicken on the floor and then put it back in the bin with the rest of the chicken. We couldn't believe it. The floor looked very disgusting. 

We mentioned it to cashier and he didn't seem bothered by it but he walked over to cook to let him know that we could see what he was doing. Instead of picking up the bin with chicken from the floor, the cook just turned around (his back towards us) and continued to marinate the chicken on the kitchen floor. 

I cannot even imagine what else could be happening in the kitchen. 

I felt really disgusted and I am definitely not coming back.
author: Jo S.

description:
On one of the hottest days in SF in like ever, my friend and I decided to check out Perilla.  Heard good things about it, and meant to stop by ever since it opened back in August replacing that Chinese restaurant I always passed on my way to Portico, the Rincon Center, and all other points east.

I ordered the beef papaya salad because it was freakin' hot and I didn't feel like sweating into a bowl of of hot noodles for lunch.  It was just what I needed: nice and cool with a hint of spiciness and just all around yummy.   I felt like I got a lot of food, too, for a dish that was under $10.  It was really, really good, man.  

Saw a few other items on the menu I'll try in future visits.
author: Charlotte M.

description: Had the five-spice chicken w/ garlic noodles and imperial roll and came out happy.   Noodles may be too soggy for some people, but they've got good garlic flavor soaked inside.  Imperial rolls are small, but are delicious with the fish sauce.  Chicken was superb: crunchy skin, juicy center.  Great lunch spot.
author: B F.

description:
I normally go to this place at least 2 or 3 times a week,but been busy at work and no one to eat with so haven't been here in a month.  They have pretty good garlic noodle.  Their chicken and beef dish with the garlic noodle are pretty tasty but a bit pricy.  If you go there betw the hours of 12 & 1, it's usually packed and there is a wait list for you to be seated...

I loved their papaya and chicken salad though.  However, their portion gets smaller recently with the same price you pay.

I missed this place and can't wait to go again soon.
author: Susie N.

description: I had the garlic noodles with chicken and it was sooo good.  I'm a lite lunch eater, so there's enough food for 2 lunches for me.  It cost me $11, but considering I'm getting 2 meals out of it, that's about even for the area.
author: Melinda H.

description:
Like Jeff N., I've been waiting to get some Pho up in here! 

Decided to stop in with my boss and order take out since the line for seating was out the door--as it always is with the lunch-hour crowd when new places open in SoMa.

We ordered the shrimp spring rolls and papaya salad with no beef. They were both decent.  I ordered Pho with thinly sliced well-done Angus  Brisket (disclaimer about myself: I like my meat mooing in general. It's a left over acquired taste from living in France. BUT with Pho, I don't eat any meat that has to cook in the broth). Unfortunately, they got my order wrong and gave me the Pho with rare flank, so, the meat was uncooked and there was a TON of it!  Too much in fact. I generally order chicken pho to avoid this whole meat conundrum but they were out of the coconut curry chicken Pho or vegetarian with tofu (not an option). 

I will definitely continue to come to Perilla to check out other items on the menu.  The garlic noodles and big well-done pieces of charbroiled Angus beef strips looked really good! That's what everyone who was seated seemed to be eating.  

As I mentioned above, they do not really have vegetarian options, unless you want to ask for them to skip the meat on whatever you. However, that still doesn't guarantee it will not be prepared with meat stock or meat products. Also, it's cash only.
author: Dee I.

description: The garlic noodles were good- but not to die for. I wasn't too impressed with the Pho either. Service is not very friendly, and the wait is always long. I'll go back here, but it's not my first choice.
author: Kristy M.

description: This place is REALLY good.  It's a place I have to be in the mood for and crave.  Their garlic noodles are yummy and I've tried it with their beef and the grilled prawns.  I prefer the prawns over the beef, but both are very flavorful.  Sometimes this place can be pretty busy so I would suggest calling in an order during lunch time.  I have yet to try their other dishes, like their pho but from what I've seen, it looks pretty good.  It's nice to have a Vietnamese restaurant by work among all these random Chinese and Japanese places.
author: Leah A.

description: Good food. Lunch rush is super busy but ordering take-out is a quick alternative.
author: Tony Z.

description:
The food is delicious and satisfying, though a bit on the greasy side.  The garlic noodles are the highlight of the menu, but don't forget your breath mint for after lunch.

There isn't a lot of sitting room, so plan on getting your meal to-go, especially if you come in peak lunch hours.
author: KC K.

description:
This is a nice alternative to the usual restaurant joints in the hood.  The imperial rolls were nice and crispy (wish they had a vegetarian version though) and the garlic prawns with vermicelli was very good.  I split them both with a friend and we left very full, it was a ton of food!

The service was quick and friendly, the food was tasty, and the line out front went very quickly.  When I'm in the mood for non-vegetarian food, I will definitely come here.  

Wish list:  
Vegetarian Options
Soup
Fish Sauce
author: Jessica B.

description: Yummmmmyyyy! If you are hungry, love garlic noodles and lemongrass beef, you have to try this place. I actually crave it, and somehow make my way over about 1-2x month. Good portions, reasonable prices, but a little on the greasy and heavy side...if youre not counting calories and looking for a great lunch spot (before 1140 if you dont want to wait), try Perilla!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I can now check this place off the list of lunch options in my work neighborhood. $9 for lukewarm curry chicken with unidentifiable chicken pieces in uninspiring curry sauce could be much better spent elsewhere. No spice, barely tasting of coconut.  All I got was a vague fatty chicken taste.  And the rice was just as blah.

Service was rushed, too, though perhaps to be expected at weekday lunch.
author: Jess Z.

description: I love this place! The garlic noodles are really good, and you absolutely cannot go wrong with the pork chops. The serving is huge! Their imperial rolls are really tasty too. The service is fast and efficient. I heard the pho is not so good as it is pretty bland. But this is coming foorm a person who drinks hot sauce out of the bottle, so...
author: Skate K.

description:
Great place, friendly service, and convenient downtown location.

HOWEVER, don't order the side of Imperial Rolls for $2.  It is ONE ROLL that's maybe 3.5 inches long, and they cut it in half.  It's the biggest rip off, and misleading thing on the menu ever.  Not a happy camper they tried to nickle and dime me for this.
author: Jacob J.

description: Five spice chicken and garlic noodles = bad breath but a little slice of heaven.
author: Melinda C.

description:
They receive one reduction in stars because their prices are steep for the quality of food.  

They further receive one reduction in stars because their hours suck.  They close the same time as all the other restaurants, which is horrible, especially for those of us who attend night classes right next door.  

Aside from that the food was decent, and the garlic noodles, I thought were pretty tasty.
author: Marisa N.

description:
Know that eating here will put you in a total garlic coma and you will be so full that you will have to take a nap under your desk when you return to work. 

It is best to get here early before the lunch crowd. This place gets really busy at lunch. Clearly there is a market for Vietnamese food in the financial district. People want their garlic noodles and they want it now! Perilla gives the masses exactly what they want - a ton of noodles and tasty meat with a couple of pieces of broccoli so that you feel like you are not being totally unhealthy. The noodles are really garlicky, so do not eat here if you have an important meeting after lunch, have a date after work, or really if you are going to come into any human contact for the rest of the day. 

Enjoy the garlic noodles and bring gum.
author: Dana H.

description: Just tried this place and it was a good surprise. The obvious differences between the normal pho place is that there isn't pho besides chicken soup. OHYEAH, there was also the bomb ass garlic noodles. Super buttery and garlicy as expected. I got it with the shrimp and imperial rolls. The shrimp was cooked well and the imperial rolls were just like any other. The real star of the show was the noodles. Prices are decent too being that it is in FiDi. I'll definitely be back for lunch in the future.
author: Edison T.

description: Per the recommendation of all the reviews before this one, I order the five spice chicken and the garlic noodles. As usual, the recommendations were right on. There was a little bit of a wait, but the line just confirmed that this is a good place to go to eat. As the lunch hour was coming to a close, the place really cleared out. So if you want to avoid the lines, go around the lunch rush. Portions are huge. I am excited to have my left-overs!
author: Joanne H.

description:
I'd give them a lot of stars for their food, but close to none for the service. If you really want a good experience with this place, get takeout and don't try to get in with the lunch crowd. Their food is pretty solid and decent fare. I'm especially fond of the garlic noodles (but don't get those if you have a date within the next 48 hours!). 

Anyway, the entrance is always awkwardly crowded and they don't do a good job of hostessing so you're left scratching your head with many other patrons. I like to duck in to the back where the takeout counter is. That is usually quick and friendly. Trying to get a table, though, is a nightmare, and the wait for food about six times as along. We once waited 45 minutes to get our food (after waiting 30 minutes for a table) and they still forgot our drinks.
Another time our waiter was being shadowed (trained?) by another waiter who interpreted our order and he mixed up everything three times.

Anyway, I keep going here because I like the food, but I don't bother eating at the actual restaurant anymore.
author: Patrice S.

description: Food still remains good - their best is the pork chops and garlic noodles.  Service wise - they're fast, but they want you out quickly.  Understandable, since the line is usually out the door.
author: Jay S.

description:
Was walking by on a sweltering SF day (not like we get many of those anyways) and decided to stop in for lunch w/my gf.

It was a nice dark wood decor w/simple design and layout, very clean lines and good color choices. Service was quick, prompt, and courteous. I ordered the Five Spices Chicken w/the Garlic Noodles and it was great. Chicken was freshly cooked and packed w/juices and flavor. The garlic noodles were plump and well flavored, perfect accompaniment to the chicken. My gf ordered the Charbroiled Beef w/the vermicelli which was cooked to juicy perfection and seasoned just right.

In all it was a refreshing lunch w/good sized portions to fill you up but not make you bloated. I'll be back here for lunch again.
author: Gary T.

description: Really good place to go for takeout lunch on a workday, but also on the pricey end of the spectrum. The garlic noodles and 5 spice chicken are really good, but kill my productivity all afternoon. I've recently taken to the papaya salad with either beef or shrimp.
author: Adam D.

description: As a Vietnamese girl growing up on rice and noodles, i am quite critical about viet restruants that arent hole in the walls, or viet fusion.  However i throughly enjoyed perilla.  the garlic noodles were tasty and hit the spot of my hungry belly.  The grilled chicken was what really impressed me, the skin was crispy and the meat was so moist it melted in your mouth.  The egg roll was ok.  Overall super greasy if your trying to be a lil healthy. but great for a splurg. i'd definitly come back here!
author: Linda T.

description:
I wanted to grab a bite to eat with a friend in the fiancial district and overall ... it was eh.  The service was slow and they didn't seem to have everything in order.  We watched a ton of hungry patrons line up outside the door while servers milled about, and quite a few people wait for their check.

The beef vermicelli was ok, we both LOOOOVE it doused in the fish sauce so we had to get another serving of the sauce in order to reach prime noodle dampness.  Other than that, the beef to noodle ratio was a little skewed on the noodle side.  Boo.  I also ordered the thai iced tea, which was only so-so and pretty watery.

I haven't really looked around for any other option in the Financial District, so this might be it for Vietnamese food (sigh).  If so, I might just stick to eating sandwiches.
author: Shay F.

description:
I had the bbq pork with garlic noodles.  My friend had the five spice chicken with garlic noodles.  The pork was fatty and so was the chicken.  It's just too oily and made us sick to our stomach after.  I usually think of Vietanamese food as healthy and fresh.  The garlic noodle is disguisting.  It's like a fusion of chinese and vietnamese.  It's just gross.  Don't get it.

The sad thing is, it's wayyyyyyyyyy over priced.  Not worth the $.
author: Mark S.

description:
I got the 5 spice chicken salad take out after hearing about the lines.  Good size portion and I happen to like dark meat so that was fine.  For those that care about sodium intake, i wish the dressing was on the side (which they did provide) but they also had dressing in the salad already.  Overall, will definitely return with friends to try the garlic noodles!

After eating at Jasmine Garden in the Castro, I lowered the rating here.
author: Yew-Hoe T.

description: How come the imperial rolls are so dainty and tiny? I was expecting it to be bigger. Eh, food was good though. Shared the shrimp garlic noodle plate with rolls and it was just enough for both of us. You're not hungry but you do crave more.
author: Mayana P.

description:
Their menu is not extensive, 6 choices of entree (generally all made the same way, but your choice of meat).  Its about $8-$10 per dish, not too bad because the portion size is sufficient for 2 small meals, if you like.  :)  for me, i finished the whole plate. 

i got the charcoaled beef, its yummy.  made well, tender and you can taste that its chared.  same for the tiger prawns.  the garlic noodle is their popular choice (you can practically see bits of garlic stir-fry into the egg noodle .... bring mint/gum for afterlunch!). the order comes very fast since all items are made the same way (meat choice, and combo with either rice, vermecelli, or garlic noodle).   seats are normally to seat 2-3.  it gets packed by 12-1pm.  so either come earlier or later.   but turnaround time is not bad, people tend to eat fast and orders come quick.   we had 5 people and waiting 10 minutes at prime time.  not bad for another lunch option in the district.  

they dont offer noodle soups (pho), which is probably something they can consider when people start to get tired of the same garlic dish.   but there are a few appetizer choices.
author: Ju D.

description: Mmmm I've tried the pork/noodle dish and the beef/noodle dish, love both.  The garlic noodles are like perfectly al dente and I really like the dipping sauce for the meat.  The service is prompt too, which is good for lunch-hour.
author: Paige W.

description:
i came here a few times at the beginning of 2009 when i was working in the area for a couple months - and i remembered it being better.

perhaps it was my choice of ordering - in the past i had ordered the dry vietnamese noodles, and it was delicious! i went there again last week and had the garlic noodles with chicken and, because it was freaking cold outside, had the soup noodles even though they seemed kind of expensive for "pho".

the garlic noodles were decent - but a bit too buttery/oily for me. the soup noodles were really disappointing though - the pork wasn't that flavorful, and the soup itself wasn't that flavorful either. i was expecting more of a pho style tasty broth, but it was more watered down here. it was a pretty big portion though, but at around $10 i would have expected better. the chicken was quite delicious though.

also - like other people mentioned, it gets busy for lunch so be prepared to wait if you arrive around noon.
author: Erin Y.

description:
Yummy! 

A little surprise in the FiDi. This place is really hopping at lunch time, but they hustle to get people seated, and don't rush the patrons that are eating. A very fine balance and nicely done. I had the pork chop with garlic noodles. Pork chop was fab, the sauce on the side also has an excellent flavor, not in love with the garlic noodles (but after burma superstar - who can do them better?) More pricey then other Vietnemese places, but that is to be expected in the city.
author: Jocelyn F.

description: When I'm craving for garlic noodles and I'm at work, I'll order from Perilla because Thanh Long and PPQ is just way to far. Their garlic noodles aren't as good but it definitely satisfies that craving. Go early before that lunch rush or call in for pick up otherwise you'll be wasting your lunch hour and then some waiting to get seated.
author: Monica N.

description:
It's happening ... popularity goes up, quality control goes down ...

I have been there once a week for the last four weeks.  Each week, something is off.  I ordered a prawn papaya salad to go ... they forgot the prawns.  Next it was the charbroiled pork with vermicelli noddles ... the pork was over cooked and dry.  Now it was the Chicken Cabbage Salad ... where's the chicken???  The salad and sauce were good but the chicken was cut way too thin and overcooked and dry.

I think I will stick with their garlic noodles with grilled prawns for now.  If that goes, I'm GONE!
author: Mrs. K.

description: I like the five spiced chicken and their fried tofu.  I don't feel like I'm over indulging myself with the fried tofu because it's small and light, not heavily battered.  My friend and I went last week at 11:45 AM and they were already full and 2 groups waiting before us.  Maybe we'll show up later next time, around 1PM or so.  I feel the staffs were rushing earlier patrons to finish and pay so they can accommodate others waiting outside the door.  Even as we were finishing around 1:30 the wait staff keep asking if we were finish ... we still had a half plate of tofu left!!  But overall I like the food!
author: Yun C.

description:
Upon my arrival, there was already a line out the door with a sign-in sheet, however, the wait was not too bad - less than 10 minutes. 

I was seated at the first table as you walk into the restaurant which I have to voice my complaint about as it was not the most attractive seating in the restaurant with the door opened along with the breeze of URINE.  uuuugghh!!!!  That was a complete turn-off which I had to pinch my nose at.  

The service and food was decent.  The imperial rolls taste test passed my palate and so did my plate of garlic noodles and grilled beef.  I do agree with some of the reviews read that the garlic noodles were a bit bland, but it was tasty enough.  Price was fair for the portion.
author: JADE L.

description: Fast Service, GREAT prices, and AMAZING garlic noodles. This is one of those places that you crave so badly it hurts. I love the beef or the 5 spice chicken--- totally bomb. I keep trying to order something aside from XX w/ garlic noodles, but I just can't because the garlic noodles are so freaking good. Perhaps I'll have another review someday on the rest of their food if I can ever eat there and not get the garlic noodles....
author: linda t.

description:
First let me confirm what you'll read in other reviews: arrive by 11:45 and you're fine.  From 11:46 on you are probably waiting unless you send someone ahead to hold a table (which they tended to let people do).

Throughout San Franicsco there are restaurants that manage to warp the price-quality continnuum.  They are able to charge much higher prices than the food would suggest they should be able to get away with -- given how much competition there is.  Mama's in North Beach was always one of those places for me.  Nothing bad about it.  It would even be a good place at 30% off-- but it is simply over-priced for what you get- and the lines make no sense at all.

Perilla seems to be one of those places as well.  The restaurant is packed by noon.  People come and go getting their take-out orders.  But for what?  And in this case the food isn't even at a levelthat you could say "at 30% less it would be a steal."  It's just not good.

Their signature garlic noodles were basically dry spaghetti with garlic and butter.  And everything else was nearly flavorless.  This was particularly noticeable in the 5-spice chicken which tasted like generic baked chicken.  But the beef was also a genuine disappointment.  Even the jasmine rice was dry and bland.   The spring rolls were okay but just okay.  The side of vegetables was 2 thin slices of cucumber per plate (or we assumed that was the role they played).

At about $12-13/person (entree + soda) they are not ripping you off.  The problem is you can get much better food even at the Rincon food court for $2-3 less.  That's what makes this restaurant really hover between 1 and 2 stars- it is both too expensive and likely over priced even if it were 20% cheaper.

The service is fine.  They don't hug you but they were friendly enough.  And like many small restaurants, the focus is on turning the tables.  Halfway through our appetizer the main courses arrived. The waittress even gave us a puzzled look as if to say, "where should I put these?"  Had we known the experience we were about to have we would have been able to offer a simple, "in the kitchen, just bring us our check"
author: William H.

description:
Garlic. Noodles. Garlic. Noodles.

This place satisfied a weeks-long search for the perfect noodles. The turnover is quick at lunch, and the prices are fine.

Garlic. Noodles. Garlic. Noodles.
author: Alexis W.

description: I came here for lunch last week and thought that they were just ok.  Maybe its because I have had days and days of noodles.  And all I got here was more noodles.  The garlic noodles was not bad..I had that with grilled tiger prawns...6 of them to be exact.  I believe it was $10.50 for the order....not bad for downtown standards.  Maybe on my next trip here....being that I don't eat noodles for days...I might enjoy it more.  BTW...my friends had the fried egg rolls and thought it was good.
author: Allison T.

description: Really good garlic noodles, big portions.  Go early to beat the rush.  Did I mention garlic noodles?  Yum.
author: Andi T.

description:
I ate her the first time with a friend, and I must say that for Vietnamese food in the Financial Area, it's pretty good! I typically order the pork and garlic noodles, and they sure do give you a hefty portion! Although the garlic noodles aren't the best I've ever had (Crustaceans), they sure come close.  

I would suggest going early though because once it hits 12pm, you have to wait for almost 30 mins to get a table.  The service is A-OK but could be a little better on their busy days.

For a sit down restaurant with good food and reasonable pricing, I love coming here for lunch.
author: Areeyla L.

description: Speaking as someone who is in love with noodles, I wasn't really all that impressed by the food here.  It was definitely crowded probably because it was lunch time and the staff was very hospitable to get us seated right away.  I ordered the garlic noodles with the five spice chicken.  The noodles were pretty bland and the chicken I was given did not look very fresh.  It was supposed to be a fillet of chicken but there were random bones in it and it was extremely oily.  I tried the veggies with garlic noodles and I thought the vegetables in that dish were extremely good but I would definitelty want some meat with that.  Overall, I didn't think it was great but according to my friends who frequent this place, they have told me it usually tastes much better so maybe I will have to try it again.
author: Rachel L.

description: So far, best vietnamese restaurant in SOMA for lunch. if you have a garlic noodle craving for lunch, this is the place to hit up b/c it's pretty off the hook here and  I usually order a side of garlic noodles to go. They stuff the container and it's only about $7. A bit on the expensive side for lunch, over $10 with tax, tip and beverage.    I usually get the grilled beef and garlic noodle combo.  i recommend coming here 15 min before noon or after 1:30 if you are on a tight lunch schedule.  Food comes fast but wait can be up to 30 minutes if you come around noon.  Don't come here for the imperial rolls, they're super tiny and expensive but crunchy.  Also, its the same owner as ppq and other sister restaurants in the city.
author: Yien S.

description:
so this review is long long long overdue, but i got an email from my former WLB (weekly lunch buddy) with a subject title of :garlic noodles and decided that this long-overdue posting was now due.

that and just the email subject alone made my mouth water.

having said that, yes, this place makes AWESOME garlic noodles...thick, perfectly cooked noodles sauteed in garlic and oil and something else and then combined with vietnamese BBQ meats of your choosing...OMG OMG OMG...

...not sure where else sells noodles like this (and if you're reading this and live in SD and know where i can get these, PLEASE TELL ME!)...

if you work in the area...and heck, even if you don't work in the area...do your taste buds a favor, screw the no-carb diet and EAT the GARLIC NOODLES at Perilla...
author: Grace O.

description: Wow. This was a welcomed surprise, this place has been here for sometime and I've never ventured in. My coworkers heard about it and said lets try it so in we went. The menu has a good variety and of course I had to try the garlic noodles. I had them with pork chops and cucumbers and boy was it good. The noodles are comfort food for sure and the pork chops are perfectly prepared. The service was super quick too, I would recommend getting there at 11:30 if you want be seated right away. The rolls in the appetizer section all looked really good too. I can't wait to go back and try other items.
author: La C.

description: papaya salad with beef was bland even with the hot fish sauce, it's chinese run place that speaks mandarin so not very authentic
author: N A.

description:
I spent $15 on 3 imperial rolls and a bowl of garlic noodles.  These are basic vietnamese fair.  If you can't get these right...

Imperial Rolls: very greasy and stale. Seemed like they were re-fried.  The grease leaking from them was dark brown.  Very disappointing.

Garlic Noodles: dry and bland.  Any grease the imperial rolls soaked up must have been from the noodles.

I was excited at first about a vietnamese restaurant near work but now I am just disappointed.  Won't go back...
author: Joe O.

description: Not an extensive menu, but that's not quite what makes or breaks a restaurant.  The dishes here are pretty simple, but pretty damn good.  Garlicky noodles + charbroiled beef + fish sauce...delicious!   This place makes for a good lunch spot.  Look to spend around $10-$15.
author: Justin L.

description: Always a line out the door at this place! It's right around the corner from the office and offers filling and flavorful Vietnamese under $10. I've gone twice and eaten 1) spring rolls appetizer 2) five spice chicken vermicelli. The spring rolls were really good - refreshing, crispy, and best of all the rice noodle wrapping had some chewiness. The five spice chicken is like Asian KFC, with a crunchy crackly skin enveloping juicy dark meat. I'd definitely come back. Minuses are the wait, and the barely decent service.
author: Richard Z.

description: This spot is really close to my work so I like to go here once in awhile during my lunch break.  I would have to say that this restaurant is usually packed during lunch hours but the waiters are great at seating you as soon as they can.  I usually go here for the garlic noodles.  They are so delicious and servedin large amounts! I also like the beef plate with garlic noodles, Papaya salad with prawns and the imperial rolls.   I really don't have any complaints about this place.  I would say it is good enough!!!
author: Nicole M.

description: My best friend works here! It sucks that this place is mainly opened for lunch but I understand cause it is in the FiDi and on the weekends/after 6pm that district is like a ghost town. He knew that I like garlic noodles! so he got me that!
author: Janet Z.

description:
mmmmMMM - garlic noodles...amazing...tender angus beef with garlic noodles...pinch me.

You walk into this tiny restaurant for lunch and the garlic aroma tickles your senses and makes your tummy say, 'gimme, gimme, gimme!' For the quality of the food, the price is just right. It was about $11.50, including tax, for my takeout beef and garlic noodle delight. The potency of the garlic was just enough, and definitely nothing as strong as garlic fries at the ball park. I'm coming back to try more dishes!!
author: Barbie D.

description:
I am falling in love with anything wrapped in rice paper, particularly shrimp rolls, and Perilla has added to my growing obsession.

Done up quick, I like how they served them as 6 mini wraps, instead of 2 or 3 larger ones. Easier for dipping, not to mention being able to eat them over a longer period of time vs. scarfing them down. Or maybe that is just me.

Note to my yelp peeps - lunch only.
author: Jason B.

description:
Perilla serves a nice, basic Vietnamese grill menu. For me, chief among the offerings is the respectable, if not dazzling, Bun Thit Nuong (charbroiled pork on the menu). If that name doesn't register, it's the delicious Vietnamese combination of vermicelli noodles atop herbs and vegetables with grilled meat and then dressed with Nuoc Cham. What holds their version back some is that its best parts are the supporting cast. The noodles, fresh herbs, and well-balanced blend of fish sauce in the dipping sauce hold everything together well.

But the grilled pork, which ought to be the star of the show, comes off merely as good. For my tastes, I'd prefer it cooked on a hotter grill to get it seared a little more, and though tasty, a little more spice wouldn't hurt. Likewise, the imperial rolls -- I like them in my Bun -- need to fry in a little bit hotter oil. They're not soggy by any means, but nor do they have that flaky, crispy wrapper of a perfect imperial roll.

And to add another voice to the request, I haven't seen Pho offered there, but would be all for them adding it!
author: Garnett L.

description:
yummmmyyyy garlic noodles that are pretty affordable in the financial district!

my fav are the pork and beef with the garlic noodles. they're about $10/11. and it looks like the same company/owners as PPQ...no wonder its so good.

big portions. either try to come early or late to beat the lunch rush b/c around noon there is always a wait.
author: Kathleen J.

description: Perilla was a surprise find, good Vietnamese food in the SOMA? I ordered the charbroiled pork w/rice noodles about $9. Next visit I'll upgrade w/garlic noodles and an imperial roll for $4 more. It's a bit pricy, but very tasty. I've been told the garlic noodles are good but no Thanh Long. Stay tuned...
author: Rich W.

description:
BEWARE: drinks have gone cheap and more expensive.  one thai ice tea is now $3 and ALL ice.  no joke.  5 small sips and ALL ice.  

that's too bad.  it was such a good value before.  wonder if rest of the stuff has gone up but less food.
author: Food Is L.

description: Perilla is a nice little Vietnamese lunch spot near work. I've been there twice with coworkers. It's very popular, and they don't take reservations, so you should expect to wait. There's not really a waiting area, so you'll probably have to wait outside. It's not overly long though. Once you get seated, the waiters are very prompt, and the food comes right out quickly. I suspect this place is related to the Perilla out near Golden Gate park, which I went to and got sick over their not good greasy garlic noodles, so I've never tried the garlic noodles here. That doesn't necessarily mean they're bad here, just because they were at the other branch, but I don't want to risk it. Both times, I've had the shrimp vermicelli.  The waiters are always helpful and good about making sure there are no peanuts on my dish, as I'm allergic. You get a nice sized bowl of noodles, with shrimps and leaves and some sauce on the side. It's tasty and depending on the type of vermicelli you get, it's $9-10. It's not greasy at all. I've had both the Vietnamese iced coffee and the thai iced tea, and both are good.  The interior is very casual. It's not a place I'd come to specifically, but only because it's right next to work, because it's nothing special, just an averagely good lunch spot. Try it if you're in the neighborhood and hungry for a fast meal!
author: Merredith L.

description:
I thought being served pho by a black guy at Treasure Island was a first.....but yesterday was the first time i've been to a viet restaurant that ran out of pho at 11:45am. We ordered spring rolls and it came with 3 dinky rolls cut in half just rolling around on the plate with a cup of fish sauce on the side. We requested lettuce to go along with the mini spring rolls and the waiter said it didn't come with those. I saw the waitress bring my 5 spice chicken rice plate to the wrong table and watched as those customers stare and point at my food before the food was presented before me. We also received several dishes of food that belonged to other tables. Place isn't that big to get orders all mixed up. Price is expensive for viet food but in the normal range in terms of fidi pricing. The viet coffee they tried to put on our table (which we told them we didn't order) also looked pretty sad. Not the drip kind you'd get at an authentic viet restaurant.
I'd still come back though to get my fix though.
author: Anita L.

description: I am a garlic noodle junkie!  I love garlic noodles... even more so then the garlic roasted crab at PPQ.  I love to see that Perilla is a fusion between both the PPQ's (crab and pho).  The combo plates is the best way to go... you get your meat and garlic noodles and sometimes you can even throw in an imperial roll.  I'm salivating just  thinking about it.  The service and food comes out once your are seated but since this is a downtown location don't except the best service ever.  They assume you know what you want almost instantly when you get seated.  They want you in and out as fast as possible to seat the long line that is going out the door.  Remember to put your name done if you have to wait and to pick up a menu  so you know what you want before you get seated!
author: Jenn Y.

description: This used to be a crappy Chinese restaurant that no ones come to even during rush hour. However, since they changed it to Perilla, I saw a long line everyday. I came here with my lunch buddy and hubby today. We had the grilled beef with vermicelli and five spiced chicken with garlic noodle ($1.5 extra). It tastes pretty good. Very reasonably priced, all items are from $6.95 - $9. I am a big fan of Vietnamese food, so I am glad that there's one by work now. Yippe
author: Ervinna L.

description: After the garlic noodles from Crustacean that left me craving more garlic noodles with real garlic in it..... my friends recommended Perilla.  We are 4 but the restaurant favours table for 2.  We waited for at least 30 mins before there is a table became free for us and the staff came by once to asked if we have to sit together.  Hello???? maybe my friends and I should put our names down the paper SEPARATELY instead of Tina X 4, then perhaps she would ask if we want sit together instead???     I ordered 5spice chicken with garlic noodles.  It was quite good even I cannot taste the 5spice but the chicken was tender and the skin was crispy.  And the noodles are made in heaven... I will try to make my own but before I do that I guess I'll go back whenever I am in the city and in that area.  Best time to go is before 11:45 am and after 1pm.
author: Bella A.

description: I never really like garlic noodles. I thought they were yappy and that nasty after taste in my mouth. However, after trying their five spice chicken rice a few times. I decided to try their garlic noodles. That was only my 2nd time trying it. I must say the garlic noodle here is not yappy and does not have nasty after taste. Ever since then, I've been coming here to eat their five spice chicken garlic noodle. Though I thought they could increase their portion for the price they are charging, I mean other places charges $2.00 cheaper than what they charged and have lots more chicken and noodles. Otherwise, food is great. Also, I thought going at 1pm would avoid the crowd. WRONG! Many times I was able to grab a table before the 1pm crowd comes along, but a few times you have to wait for a table around 5 or 10 minutes (not that bad comparing to the 12pm crowd). I also want to comment on their service; last time I went there they had a hiccup on my order. I sat there for 30 minutes and my food went to another table that ordered later than me. My friend and I got mad and they finally realized they forgot about our table. So they gave us a discount. So that makes up for it! I would come back for take outs and avoid the long waits and forgotten table.
author: Elaine C.

description:
i'm a sucker for garlic noodles. 

they make me happy and sleepy
author: Lia A.

description: If you want flavorless, greasy, lukewarm and overpriced vietnamese food, this is your place.  I ordered five spice chicken with garlic noodles today and it'll be my last time ordering from here.
author: winnie l.

description: Perilla is a hot spot for lunch and always pretty crowded if you arrive after 11:45. It's so popular not because it's particularly that great, but I think there's a lack of Vietnamese food in the area. The menu is quite small. I usually get the five spice chicken either with rice or with noodle soup. The noodles isn't the pho noodles tho - wish it were!
author: S H.

description: I kept it real and went for the vermicelli salad bowl with five spice chicken.  It was definitely tasty, but at $9 a plate it's hard for me to rave about it.  I could easily get a similar meal for $5-6 outside of the financial district.  Darn the financial district's high rents for keeping cheap and tasty Asian places out of walking distance (*shakes right fist in front of face and frowns*).
author: Krystle S.

description:
Nice lunch place. 
When I first visited the place, there was a significant amount of people waiting outside. The place is in the middle of busy financial buildings and right next to G.G University, so I figured line outside was inevitable. We waited around 15 min for a table. Their main dishes comprise of Vietnamese style rice plates with your choice of rice, veggies, or garlic noodles. I personally liked the garlic noodles the best. Fair price, decent service, good food. Couldn't really complain much.
author: Hong S.

description: Very good Vietnamese food.  I have been here several times for lunch and have tried several of the noodle bowls - which are delicious.  Garlic noodles are also great. Service is quick and friendly.  Get there early for lunch - by noon there is often a line out the door -  which is my only complaint - the food is so good and the place is so popular that the line to get a table or for take-out stretches the length of the restaurant, which sometimes makes eating here a little rushed and hectic - but, I think, a price worth paying since the food is so good and so reasonably priced.
author: David P.

description: Great food. Get their early as it can get crowded. I normally go for the to-go option and head across the street to the park above the parking lot the chow down on the scrumptious food.
author: Johnson H.

description: All I have to say is that I'm not that impressed. Sure this place is packed during lunch time, but I think it's because some people haven't had authentic vietnamese food. The food was just ehhh ok. The garlic noodles weren't that tasty. The five spice chicken was actually alright, but only after pouring all the fish sauce over it. Conclusion...not worth it.
author: Wendy L.

description: What a treat!  I was craving some Vietnamese food on New Year's Eve in San Francisco and decided to stop by here with a couple friends for lunch.  The restaurant was very clean and nice.  We ordered Shrimp spring rolls to start, very tasty!  I had an Iced Coffee, along with Tiger prawns and Garlic noodles.  All very delicious.... definitely the garlic noodles!  The nice thing is that you can order a side of garlic noodles for only $2.50.  I thought it was funny that on the menu, they had a "Heaping order of Garlic noodles" for $6.50 (I think) but after trying it, I wouldn't have minded getting my own heaping order... great food, clean environment, pretty good service, and reasonably priced for San Francisco
author: Shali N.

description: More like fusion and not authentic vietnamese, always crowded and busy, service is kindda unpleasant and cold.
author: Joiera C.

description:
yeah the pho  is a bit overpriced at 7.50 so i ordered the noodles with charbroiled pork. not bad for $7.50, which is the same price as the international food center (the only other vietnamese place near my work)

the pork was good, and the fish sauce abundant.  it would have been better if they added some other greens beside lettuce.  also you need the marinated carrots yo.  its a staple in vietnamese cuisine.  how can you no do?
author: Huyness D.

description: I always order the garlic noodles with five spice chicken.  That dish is awesome.  The noodle are very tasty, although I've occasionally gotten noodles that were browned on one side, so I suspect they make large batches and the noodles on the bottom of the pan get "cooked" a little more.  The chicken has a lot of flavor, has crispy skin, and is juicy inside.  This place gets super busy for lunch, so show up by 11:45 at least or risk a long wait.
author: Daniel J.

description: I had met some friends here for lunch; the food was pretty good and prices are more than reasonable. I had the garlic noodles with grilled prawns and it was super tasty. I'm never in this area and now that I know it's here, I'll be ordering take out for lunch too.
author: David D.

description: Gives me my Vietnamese fix when I'm working in the city.  Fast to-go service.  Sat down to eat here a couple of times... the steamed dumplings too a while but that's how it goes with steamed dumplings.  Thick dough, the way it should be when steamed.  Yum!
author: Jade K.

description: Garlic noodles are insane...I love their salads, and their beef, but their chicken has a funky consistency.  It is always really busy at lunch so you are best off if you come on the earlier side (before 1145) or later side (after 1).
author: Julia B.

description: Stopped here for lunch with friends, and wasn't impressed. The portions are large, but the food wasn't noteworthy. The shrimp rolls were OK, the peanut sauce was OK, the soup was, again just OK. And there is butter on the garlic noodles! Ick, big disappointment. The service was fairly fast, but I seemed to get a lot of servers' arms in my face because they reach all the way across the table instead of walking around to the other side of the table to grab dishes.
author: Corinthia C.

description: I'm so excited there is finally a vietnamese place in this neighborhood!  It is a bit overprices (1 imperial roll for $2.30), but the food is tasty.  My beef was slightly undercooked if that sort of thing bothers you.  Portions are big and I can't wait to try more stuff on the menu.  Now if only they would serve pho...
author: Mitzi C.

description: This is a nice lunch option. The service is a notch above what most Vietnamese restaurants are like. They're not being rude, that's just how it is. Understandably, there are so many options in the city that it may work against them, but I would rather have indifferent service than for them to awkardly try to be friendly - that would be like my vietnamese parents showing affection, just weird. The price point is ok, not great for an Asian place but definitely less than an equivalent amount and quality of food anywhere else. And really why do they have to charge rock-bottom prices just because it's Asian food? I pay $10 for lunch at Boudin for crying out loud.
author: Mimi N.

description: At first I was a little thrown off by their prices, but the portions are huge. I had the five spice chicken with garlic noodles. YUM. The chicken wasn't my favorite because it was a boneless drumstick. I'm more of a breast man myself. But the garlic noodles were excellent. I could barely finish my plate but I forced it. I was in a food coma after but it was worth it. Too bad I discovered this place on my last day working in the city. We ate after 1pm on a Wednesday and it wasn't crowded at all. The service was fast and friendly. They let us have 3 separate checks without any complaints.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Best part of the meal:  Vietnamese salty lemonade soda
Next best:  garlic noodles
Third:  grilled pork
