Last:  5-spice chicken.  Couldn't taste the five spices and the chicken meat itself had no flavor, though it was tender and juicy.

Next time I'm getting just the lemonade and garlic noodles.
author: Sumomo O.

description:
This place used to be decent.  Not great.  But good in an average sort of way.  Now that they've gone wacky with their prices though, it isn't even average anymore.

There aren't many Asian lunch places in this neighborhood that can hold a candle to the ones out on Clement.  For awhile though, Perilla was taking a run at it.  You could get a plate/bowl of pretty respectable Vietnamese food for $7.50 or so.  Which, IMHO, is about what it should be. Now, they charge $8 for a bowl of vermicelli pork and an extra $2 for the spring roll that used to come free in the dish...and does in EVERY OTHER Vietnamese restaurant in the city.  

Whatever.  I'm not going back.
author: Joseph S.

description:
First time trying this place today, had the 5 spice chicken with garlic noodles, both the chicken and the noodles were DELICIOUS!  Wish I can eat it everyday (but I bet the noodles go right to my waist as fat :( )  The noodles had a lot more garlic than some of the garlic fries I've eaten.  But with the price being around $10 per dish, I certainly won't be eating it everyday.  

I wonder if this is authentic Vietnamese food though... this is really the first time I had garlic noodle in a Vietnamese restaurant, I thought the only kinda noodle they serve is pho.
author: Peggy M.

description: Finally, a tasty Vietnamese joint near work! I ordered the grilled pork with rice with a side of imperial rolls. The grilled pork was lean and super flavorful with nicely charred edges. The fish sauce went perfectly with the crispy imperial rolls. And the portion was sizable and reasonably priced. As a bonus, the decor is clean and modern and clean!
author: Jennifer C.

description: subpar viet food. Not authentic and overpriced for sure. Is this place even run by vietnamese ppl? I don't think so. Prices on their website are lower than what they actually charge which is misleading. Front door also smelt like urine during my last visit... eww
author: Anna L.

description: I tried this place yesterday for my co-workers birthday lunch. I had the charbroiled beef w/ garlic noodles instead of steamed rice. YUMMY! I think the garlic noodles were pretty good although I still love the ones from PPQ. The imperial rolls are really tiny. I swear I've seen lumpia shanghai bigger then that so we had to double our order. Pretty busy during lunch time thank god we went early. The menu is really simple. Overall, Pretty good vietnamese food in the Financial District!
author: Vanessa C.

description: Great food, generous portions, friendly service.  Price was right, too.
author: john s.

description: I've never set foot in the restaurant, but my wife works nearby.  Recently, she brought some leftover garlic noodles and papaya salad home and I must say it was "AWESOME".  Today she brought some garlic noodles and papaya salad home again and it was just as delicious as the first time.  I've had garlic noodles at several places, but this place has the best by far!
author: Jess G.

description: Papaya salad and five spice chicken earn this place four stars. Great place for lunch, but need to avoid peak hours.
author: Joanne X.

description: I was in the mood for a "hearty lunch" so I had lunch here again and the food seemed to be better.  It probably has to do with the fact that I ordered another dish.  Today, I had the five spice chicken with garlic noodles and it was yummy!  My girlfriend ordered the charbroiled pork which was really good, too.  We both ordered thai iced teas which seemed really strong and so sweet that I had to ask for more milk.  Other than that, we were able to get a table in less than 5 minutes (arriving there at 12:30), the service was fast, the food was good and the bill was reasonable (didn't order the imperial rolls this time!).  Although I need a mint or two, I'm a fan.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Been waiting for a Pho restaurant to open in Soma!  Can't say that the Pho is that great, a little too watery, but at least I can now satisfy my Pho cravings near where I work.  I am from San Jose, so I am used to good Pho.  The portion is also a little small, but what can you expect for Soma.  We also had the fresh and deep fried rolls.  Those were good....

Grace, you are too slow!  I gave you 3 days to Yelp first ;P


-------------------------------

Ok, have to edit this... no more pho served here!!!
author: Jeff N.

description: I realized that Perilla just opened, but during the lunch rush, it's a looooooong time to wait for some murky-broth pho.  It's better than Pho Hoa, but that's not saying much...
author: Suo L.

description: The green papaya salad with beef was amazing and huge. It is worth the money i paid.
author: Victoria D.

description: I thought the food here was pretty good.  We ordered pork spring rolls/garlic noodles/five spice chicken w/rice.  Garlic noodle was a bit salty but other than that the food was decent.  I wish they would open for dinner as well!
author: JenJen W.

description: Garlic noodles ftw.  $10.95 for a plate with prawns a little on the pricey side but still tastes damn good.
author: kenny w.

description:
If there is one rule to live by when it comes to Vietnamese food it is never patronize a "Vietnamese" restaurant that is owned and operated by Chinese.  That is Chinese people do not cook Vietnamese food well.  Basically, non-Vietnamese do not cook Vietnamese food well.  The spices are often not on point or even true to the cuisine.

As for Perilla, it is exactly that, a restaurant with Chinese cooks horribly bastardizing Vietnamese cooking.  It is food for the downtown office lunch crowd that's really trying not to overwhlem the gentile palate.  It breaks my heart to know that some people will think it really is Vietnamese food.

Don't be a dumb ass like me, keep it real and find yourself a Vietnamese owned and operated restaurant.
author: Viet V.

description: It's always full during lunch and there's a line outside everyday.  It's good, filling, big portions and efficient service.  We always have the grilled lemongrass pork with garlic noodles.  Can't go wrong with that.  Imperial rolls are good as well.  Good place to go to for lunch.
author: Cj P.

description: It was ok.  The 5 spice chicken was generic but the service and speed were good.
author: R B.

description: the garlic noodles are all i've had here.  they are good, real good.  my problem is that i have them, and then comatose in work from them though as they are a heavy carb.
author: Andrew r.

description:
get the 5-spice chicken.  everything else isn't worth the calories.
the garlic noodles are good but on the softer side.  if you are a stickler for great garlic noodles, go to crustacean.

it offers a good variety to the lunchtime selection but i don't think i can go more often than once every 2 mths or so.

avoid lunchtime, the queue is unjustifiably long.
author: tc h.

description: I ordered the grilled pork with vermicelli noodles and the pork was not fresh.  You can smell the oldness of the pork and some were not even cooked.  The service is not the greatest and it's also pricey for what you get.  It's not true Vietnamese food but it's really the only Vietnamese place in the financial district.
author: Mary L.

description: Working in the Financial District, Vietnamese food alone is hard to come by, nonetheless, flavorful Vietnamese food.  Often times I complain to my co-workers how I wish my favorite Vietnamese restaurant PPQ, would open another location downtown.  Dreams do come true - well. . .almost.  My friend and I decided to try Perilla yesterday since we both had heard about it but hadn't had the chance to try it.  Even when we were waiting for our table we both exchanged our deep affection for PPQ on Irving and how nothing comes close to the quality and flavor of the dishes there.  My co-worker went recently and raved about the garlic noodles, but my immediate response was how could it be any better than the ones at PPQ Dungeness Island?  Anyhow, I ordered the charbroiled pork chop over garlic noodles while my friend ordered the charbroiled beef over garlic noodles.  We both agreed both meats were a bit overdone and dry, but the garlic noodles were very tasty.  I blame the thin-ness of the pork chop because the flavors were definitely there.  The texture of the garlic noodles was perfect and the garlic wasn't over the top nor too buttery.  As I was paying the bill, I noticed that the owner of my beloved PPQ on Irving was at the counter and then it hit me - could it really be true?  PPQ has finally hit the Financial District?  I'll definitely be going back because it's the yummiest Vietnamese food in the area - hands down.  Props to the owner of PPQ on making a move to the FiDi.
author: Jana H.

description: The price is not really that cheap, but the food tastes very good. Got the 5-spice chicken with garlic noodles, a couple florets of broccoli.  About $10 for lunch. Its pretty filling. The garlic noodles are pretty good, but not to-die-for, I guess its hard to live up to all the hype. The service is very quick and good though.
author: Dijon Y.

description:
ate here 3 times..loved it each time..I've had the charbroiled beef w/ garlic noodles twice - oh, so good! they give you almost half a plate of garlic noodles..downside is, you have to add the noodles to your order (which is $1.50 more) brings your meal of beef and noodles to 10 bucks.. the other time I had the beef papaya salad..again very yummy...

the service is good..I've been going there for lunch (12:30PM)..peak time, there's always a line out the door..but, each time I've been able to get a table for 2 within 5 -10min.. then they're quick to bring out your order.. I highly recommend this place..especially since there's a lack of vietnamese food around this area..
author: Linda Y.

description: This is the third time I dined here. So far so good. I've been pretty pleased with the food. I tried the Garlic Noodle w/ charboiled beef; Charboiled pork w/ vermicelli and the beef papaya salad.  Today the nuoc nam was really sweet but a little hot sauce will off set that..... Totally agree, don't sit by the door way.... Ewww when that wind pick up you will a surprize of urine smell. nasty...... They did take off pho off the menu. I think they removed pho off the menu item because they want to get more customers in and out during lunch time. Can't rush a customer who's enjoying theire hot pho soup.... You know what I mean....
author: d l.

description: i don't normally want to go eat vietnamese food but i was told to give this place a shot. the food was DELICIOUS!! i thorougly enjoyed the garlic noodles and the chicken salad. i can't wait to eat here again. it's too bad they are only open limited hours!!
author: Jenn O.
